_LIBRARY/Literature/Neugebauer2019.title: A family of radical halogenases for the engineering of amino-acid-based products
_LIBRARY/Literature/Neugebauer2019.content:
A family of radical halogenases for the engineering of amino-acid-based products
📄 Metadata

Authors: Monica E. Neugebauer, Kiera H. Sumida, Jeffrey G. Pelton, Jonathan L. McMurry, Jorge A. Marchand, Michelle C. Y. Chang
Year: 2019
Journal: Nature Chemical Biology
DOI: 10.1038/s41589-019-0355-x
Citekey: Neugebauer2019

📚 Abstract
The integration of synthetic and biological catalysis enables new approaches to the synthesis of small molecules by combining the high selectivity of enzymes with the reaction diversity offered by synthetic chemistry. While organohalogens are valued for their bioactivity and utility as synthetic building blocks, only a handful of enzymes that carry out the regioselective halogenation of unactivated {\rm{C}}_{sp^3}{-}{\rm{H}}bonds have previously been identified. In this context, we report the structural characterization of BesD, a recently discovered radical halogenase from the FeII/α-ketogluturate-dependent family that chlorinates the free amino acid lysine. We also identify and characterize additional halogenases that produce mono- and dichlorinated, as well as brominated and azidated, amino acids. The substrate selectivity of this new family of radical halogenases takes advantage of the central role of amino acids in metabolism and enables engineering of biosynthetic pathways to afford a wide variety of compound classes, including heterocycles, diamines, α-keto acids and peptides.

_LIBRARY/Literature/Stalder-2024.title: Biocatalytic Synthesis of L-Pipecolic Acid by a Lysine Cyclodeaminase: Batch and Flow Reactors
_LIBRARY/Literature/Stalder-2024.content:
Literature Summary
SpLCD catalyzes the transformation of L-lysine to L-pipecolic acid without the need for external cofactors. The enzyme was immobilized efficiently and showed stable activity under continuous flow for several days. Rotating-bed and packed-bed reactors were tested.
Batch: >95% conversion at 50 mM L-lysine after 24h at 37°C.
Flow: Continuous operation at 10 mM L-lysine with ~80% conversion over 140 hours runtime.
Rotating-bed immobilization tested with SpinChem.

_LIBRARY/Literature/tedersReversiblePhot.title: Reversible Photoswitchable Inhibitors Generate Ultrasensitivity in Out-of-Equilibrium Enzymatic Reactions
_LIBRARY/Literature/tedersReversiblePhot.content:
Reversible Photoswitchable Inhibitors Generate Ultrasensitivity in Out-of-Equilibrium Enzymatic Reactions
📄 Metadata

Authors: Michael Teders, Aleksandr A. Pogodaev, Glenn Bojanov, Wilhelm T. S. Huck
Year: 2021
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society
DOI: 10.1021/jacs.0c12956
Citekey: tedersReversiblePhotoswitchableInhibitors2021

📎 Attached Files

Full Text PDF

📚 Abstract
Ultrasensitivity is a ubiquitous emergent property of biochemical reaction networks. The design and construction of synthetic reaction networks exhibiting ultrasensitivity has been challenging, but would greatly expand the potential properties of life-like materials. Herein, we exploit a general and modular strategy to reversibly regulate the activity of enzymes using light and show how ultrasensitivity arises in simple out-of-equilibrium enzymatic systems upon incorporation of reversible photoswitchable inhibitors (PIs). Utilizing a chromophore/warhead strategy, PIs of the protease α-chymotrypsin were synthesized, which led to the discovery of inhibitors with large differences in inhibition constants (Ki) for the different photoisomers. A microfluidic flow setup was used to study enzymatic reactions under out-of-equilibrium conditions by continuous addition and removal of reagents. Upon irradiation of the continuously stirred tank reactor with different light pulse sequences, i.e., varying the pulse duration or frequency of UV and blue light irradiation, reversible switching between photoisomers resulted in ultrasensitive responses in enzymatic activity as well as frequency filtering of input signals. This general and modular strategy enables reversible and tunable control over the kinetic rates of individual enzyme-catalyzed reactions and makes a programmable linkage of enzymes to a wide range of network topologies feasible.
🖍️ Annotations (Imported: 2025-04-27 4:22 pm)

Immobilization of e-SpLCD on epoxide-functionalized resins (EP400) for use in batch and continuous flow biotransformations. Immobilization performed at low temperature to preserve enzyme activity.

_old/first_QuartzPages_WOB/Biocatalysis.title: Biocatalysis
_old/first_QuartzPages_WOB/Biocatalysis.content:
Biocatalysis: Definition and Scope
Definition
Biocatalysis refers to the use of natural catalysts, such as enzymes or whole cells, to perform chemical transformations on organic compounds. These biocatalysts are derived from biological systems and can be employed in their native form or after modification through protein engineering techniques. Biocatalysis represents an interdisciplinary field at the intersection of biochemistry, molecular biology, organic chemistry, and chemical engineering.
Core Principles
Biocatalysts operate under the same fundamental principles as traditional chemical catalysts—they accelerate chemical reactions by lowering activation energy barriers without being consumed in the process. However, they differ from conventional catalysts in several critical aspects:

Selectivity: Biocatalysts typically exhibit exceptional chemo-, regio-, and stereoselectivity.
Mild Reaction Conditions: Most biocatalytic processes operate under physiological or near-physiological conditions (aqueous media, ambient temperature, atmospheric pressure, neutral pH).
Catalytic Efficiency: Many enzymes approach theoretical catalytic perfection with kcat/KM values approaching the diffusion limit (10^8-10^9/ Ms).
Complexity: Biocatalysts possess complex three-dimensional structures that enable sophisticated molecular recognition and catalytic mechanisms.

Historical Context
The field of biocatalysis has evolved through several distinct phases:

First Wave (Pre-1980s): Utilization of native enzymes in aqueous environments, primarily in the food and pharmaceutical industries.
Second Wave (1980s-1990s): Introduction of protein engineering and recombinant DNA technology, enabling the production of enzymes from any organism in convenient hosts.
Third Wave (2000s-Present): Development of directed evolution methods leading to highly engineered biocatalysts with properties far beyond their natural counterparts.
Fourth Wave (Emerging): Integration of biocatalysis with synthetic biology, machine learning, computational design, and high-throughput methodologies.

Sources of Biocatalysts
Enzymes for biocatalytic applications can be sourced through several avenues:
Commercial Sources

Purified enzymes or lyophilized crude cell lysates available directly from chemical vendors
Enzyme libraries and kits for screening (oxidoreductases, transferases, hydrolases, etc.)
Custom gene synthesis based on known amino acid sequences

Natural Product Biosynthetic Enzymes

Mining biosynthetic pathways of specialized metabolites
Fe(II) and 2-oxoglutarate-dependent enzymes that catalyze challenging reactions
Diels-Alderases, halogenases, methyltransferases, and other biosynthetic enzymes

Metagenomic and In Silico Screening

Environmental DNA libraries from diverse sources (marine sponges, soil, microbiomes)
Functional-based screening using colorimetric assays or droplet microfluidics
Sequence-based screening to find enzymes with similarity to known catalysts
In silico mining of genomic databases

Enzyme Engineering and Design
Directed Evolution

Creation of genetic diversity through random mutagenesis, site saturation, DNA shuffling
High-throughput screening methods (colony-based assays, microfluidics, FACS)
Iterative rounds of mutation and selection to improve desired properties
Ultra-high-throughput screening of 10^5-10^8 variants in picoliter droplets

Computational Enzyme Design

Quantum mechanics modeling of active sites and transition states (“theozyme” design)
Integration with Rosetta and other protein design software
Molecular dynamics simulations to incorporate protein flexibility
Identifying distal mutations that impact catalysis through conformational changes
Shortest path mapping and ancestral scaffold approaches

Non-Canonical Amino Acids

Expanding the genetic code to incorporate novel functionalities
Genetically encoded non-natural amino acids for new catalytic mechanisms
Engineering aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases for specific non-canonical amino acids
Enhanced nucleophilic catalysis through N-methylhistidine incorporation

Cascade Development
Biocatalytic cascades enable multistep transformations without intermediate isolation, offering significant advantages in efficiency and sustainability. Development follows a design-build-optimize cycle:
Design Phase

Retrosynthetic analysis using principles of bio-retrosynthesis
Computer-aided synthesis planning tools (e.g., RetroBioCat)
Linear, orthogonal, or cyclic cascade design
Consideration of cofactor requirements and potential incompatibilities

Build Phase

Enzyme selection or discovery for each step
Implementation options: in vitro (cell-free extracts), in vivo (whole cells), or hybrid approaches
Individual validation of cascade steps before combination

Optimize Phase

Protein engineering to overcome pathway bottlenecks
Process optimization and enzyme immobilization strategies
Pathway flux maximization

Industrial Examples

Evonik’s whole-cell cascade for diamine production from renewable dicarboxylic acids
GSK’s KRED-IRED system for GSK2879552 synthesis via hydrogen-borrowing cascade
Merck’s nine-enzyme cascade for HIV inhibitor islatravir synthesis

Industrial Applications and Key Metrics
Metrics for Evaluating Biocatalysts

Productivity (g/lh): Amount of product made per reactor volume and time
Yield (g/g): Amount of product relative to substrate added
Turnover (mol/mol): Amount of product per amount of biocatalyst
E factor (g/g): Waste produced relative to product made
Process mass intensity: Raw material input relative to product made

Pharmaceutical Industry Applications

Sitagliptin manufacture using an engineered transaminase (200 g/l substrate loading)
LSD1 inhibitor GSK2879552 synthesis using an evolved imine reductase
Molnupiravir synthesis for COVID-19 treatment

Bulk and Fine Chemical Production

Acrylamide production using nitrile hydratase (300-500 g/l, 50-100 g/lh productivity)
(−)-Ambrox fragrance synthesis using engineered squalene hopene cyclase
Enzymatic hydrolysis for flavor compounds (δ-decalactone)

Reproducibility and Data Deposition
Biocatalysis Databases

UniProt, BioCatNet, and BRENDA for enzyme sequence and activity data
PrenDB for substrate/product information on prenyltransferases
CAZy for carbohydrate-active enzymes
Need for comprehensive databases capturing reaction outcomes and conditions

Standardization Efforts

STRENDA (Standards for Reporting Enzyme Data) guidelines
Challenges in data standardization across different scientific communities
Smart-laboratory infrastructure for improved data capture

Future Directions
The field of biocatalysis continues to evolve rapidly, with several emerging trends:

Integration with Synthetic Biology: Engineering of entire metabolic pathways for complex transformations
Artificial Metalloenzymes: Combining the selectivity of enzymes with the versatility of metal catalysis
Promiscuous Enzymatic Activity: Exploiting and enhancing secondary activities of natural enzymes
New Reaction Environments: Expanding biocatalysis to extreme conditions and non-conventional media
Sustainable Chemistry: Development of enzymatic alternatives to traditional chemical processes
Machine Learning Integration: Accelerating enzyme discovery and optimization
De Novo Biocatalysts: Creating entirely new enzymes for reactions not found in nature

Challenges and Limitations
Despite significant advances, several challenges remain:

Enzyme Stability: Improving operational stability under industrial conditions
Substrate Scope: Expanding the range of acceptable substrates
Cofactor Regeneration: Developing efficient systems for cofactor recycling
Process Integration: Combining biocatalysis with traditional chemical steps
Economic Viability: Reducing costs to compete with established chemical processes
C-C Bond Formation: Limited enzyme platforms for carbon-carbon bond forming reactions
Scalable Oxidative Enzymes: Challenges in scaling up P450s and other oxidases
Rapid Development: Meeting the accelerated timelines demanded by industry

_old/output/Papers/biocatalytic-synthesi.title: Biocatalytic Synthesis of l-Pipecolic Acid by a Lysine
_old/output/Papers/biocatalytic-synthesi.content:
TL;DR

Engineered Lysine Cyclodeaminase (e-SpLCD) converts l-Lysine to l-Pipecolic Acid (l-PA) with high efficiency.
Immobilization of e-SpLCD on microparticles enables continuous flow synthesis, achieving full conversion in 90 minutes.

What they did
The study uses an engineered Lysine Cyclodeaminase from Streptomyces pristinaespiralis (e-SpLCD) to convert l-Lysine into l-Pipecolic Acid through a biocatalytic process, both in batch and continuous flow reactors.
Why it matters
l-PA is valuable for pharmaceuticals like anesthetics and immuno-suppressants; this method aims to provide a more efficient and sustainable production route compared to traditional chemical methods.
Limitations

Lower conversion yields were observed in the SpinChem® reactor compared to free e-SpLCD.

_old/output/Papers/https-doiorg101038s41.title: https:/ / doi.org/10.1038/s41589-019-0355-x
_old/output/Papers/https-doiorg101038s41.content:
TL;DR

BesD is a radical halogenase that chlorinates free amino acids without requiring carrier proteins.
This discovery expands the biosynthetic potential of radical halogenation.

What they did
The study characterizes BesD, a novel FeII/αKG-dependent radical halogenase that directly chlorinates lysine, and identifies additional members of this family capable of chlorinating various amino acids.
Why it matters
This work aims to expand the utility of radical halogenases in biological production by enabling direct modification of simple building blocks like free amino acids.
Limitations

The text does not provide details on the specific mechanisms or detailed structural insights beyond the crystal structure.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/01_Bornsch.title: 01_Bornscheuer_2012_Nature
backbone/core_reviews/summary/01_Bornsch.content:
Engineering the third wave of biocatalysis (Bornscheuer et al., Nature 2012)
Citation & scope
Perspective/review that coins and frames the “third wave” of biocatalysis: directed evolution + DNA tech + bioinformatics turning bespoke enzymes into robust, process-fit catalysts; surveys enabling methods and industrial case studies (Lipitor side chain, sitagliptin, others).
Thesis / what’s new
Advances in sequencing/synthesis, smarter evolution, and computational analysis allow large, rapid improvements in stability, activity, and selectivity, so enzymes are now engineered to fit process specs (not vice-versa). The article formalizes a free-energy/ΔG design view that links process goals to structural changes and library strategies.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Three waves — 1st: immobilized/stable natural enzymes for classic products; 2nd: early structure-based engineering expanding scope; 3rd: directed evolution with smarter, smaller libraries and rapid DNA build/read.


ΔG-guided engineering — Map target property gains (stability/selectivity/rate) to free-energy changes, pick strategies (e.g., surface ion pairs, prolines, reshaped pockets), then deploy focused libraries near causal regions. (Fig. 2).


DNA & informatics stack — Cheap gene synthesis (whole-gene/library), massive NGS/metagenomes, consensus/ancestral analyses, structure databases → small, high-quality libraries with high active-variant fraction.


Library & screening tactics — Random ↔ semirational (active-site saturation; reduced alphabets), ProSAR stats to combine beneficial mutations; FACS/IVC, growth-based selections, and continuous evolution in E. coli.


From whole cells to isolated enzymes — Trend toward isolated enzymes (more active per mass, easier DS, harsher media tolerance), with whole-cell exceptions when cofactor recycling and multienzyme logic dominate.


Process & sustainability — Numerous Presidential Green Chemistry Awards to biocatalysis; case-based evidence that evolved enzymes cut waste, metals, energy and simplify work-ups at scale.


Key exemplars & metrics (table-ready)


Sitagliptin TA: 27 mutations (8.2% of 330 aa); converts 200 g/L ketone to product, 99.95% ee, 92% yield; +53% productivity & metal-free vs Rh/Josiphos route.


Lipitor side chain (Fig. 3): alternative KRED+HHDH, nitrilase (handles up to 3 M substrate; 96% conv., 98.5% ee), or aldolase route (sets two stereocenters); one KRED/HHDH intermediate at >100 t·yr⁻¹ rate.


ProSAR-guided HHDH: ~4,000× rate gain with 35 substitutions (14% of 254 aa) identified statistically across big random libraries.


Scale portfolio (Table): many KRED/TA/oxidase/hydrolase processes (e.g., ezetimibe, boceprevir/telaprevir intermediates, simvastatin acylation) enabled by stability, solvent tolerance, product inhibition relief.


Green awards: 16 biocatalysis wins since 2000 (e.g., sitagliptin, atorvastatin intermediate, PLA, 1,3-PDO, biodiesel).


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)


Design predictability: distal mutation effects & non-additivity/epistasis remain hard; need better models of dynamics and transition states.


De-novo design: successful but weak starters that still require evolution (Kemp, Diels–Alder).


Practical constraints: DNA synthesis cost/length; thermodynamic ceilings for some non-natural transformations; structure under process conditions vs crystal conditions may diverge.


Outlook (authors)
Expect more 30–40-mutation catalysts routinely tailored in months, broader promiscuity-to-new-function upgrades, tighter nanomaterial/scaffold integration, and continued shift to process-fit enzyme design as a standard part of synthesis.
Tags
Third wave; ΔG-guided engineering; semirational libraries; ProSAR; FACS/IVC/continuous evolution; isolated vs whole-cell; Lipitor side chain (KRED/HHDH/nitrilase/aldolase); sitagliptin TA; Green metrics/awards; scalability.
Biocatalysis Field Topics - Extracted from Key Review
Source: Bornscheuer, U.T., Huisman, G.W., Kazlauskas, R.J., Lutz, S., Moore, J.C. & Robins, K. “Engineering the third wave of biocatalysis.” Nature 485, 185-194 (2012).
Core Topics Identified
1. Directed Evolution
Definition: Iterative cycles of random amino-acid changes in proteins, followed by selection or screening for improved variants. Key Quote: “The methods are now commonly called directed evolution… The initial versions of this technology involve iterative cycles of random amino-acid changes in a protein, followed by selection or screening of the resulting libraries for variants with improved enzyme stability, substrate specificity and enantioselectivity.”
2. Protein Engineering Strategies
Definition: Rational, semi-rational, and computational approaches to enzyme improvement. Key Quote: “Converting these case studies into engineering principles will require using free energy to connect the design goals to the structural changes needed… Large changes in properties require large changes in free energy.”
3. Industrial Pharmaceutical Biocatalysis
Definition: Commercial-scale enzymatic processes for drug intermediate synthesis. Key Quote: “The numerous biocatalytic routes scaled up for pharmaceutical manufacturing demonstrate their competitiveness with traditional chemical processes.” Examples: Atorvastatin (Lipitor), sitagliptin, duloxetine synthesis
4. Ketoreductases (KREDs)
Definition: Enzymes for stereoselective reduction of ketones to alcohols. Key Quote: “KRED-based processes have now replaced whole-cell reductions and metal–ligand-based chemocatalysis, which were the industry standards during the past decade.”
5. Transaminases
Definition: Enzymes for stereoselective synthesis of chiral amines. Key Quote: “Recent engineering expanded the substrate range of transaminases to ketones with two bulky substituents… yielded an engineered amine transaminase that can replace the transition-metal-based hydrogenation catalyst for sitagliptin manufacture.”
6. Cofactor Regeneration
Definition: Systems for continuous recycling of expensive cofactors (NADH, NADPH). Key Quote: “As predicted by Schmid et al. in their forward-looking review in 2001, continuous regeneration of cofactors and a wider range of enzymes have been reported in the past ten years.”
7. Stability Engineering
Definition: Improving enzyme thermostability, solvent tolerance, and operational stability. Key Quote: “Engineered enzymes can remain stable at 60°C in solutions containing organic solvents, can accept new substrates and can catalyse new non-natural reactions.”
8. Substrate Scope Expansion
Definition: Engineering enzymes to accept non-natural substrates. Key Quote: “Novel enzymes are needed today to convert biomass into second- and third-generation biofuels, materials and chemicals.”
9. Green Chemistry Applications
Definition: Environmentally friendly biocatalytic processes. Key Quote: “Biocatalysis, using either enzyme technology or whole cells, has won 16 awards since 2000… Biocatalysts are made from renewable sources and are biodegradable and non-toxic.”
10. Multi-enzyme Systems & Cascades
Definition: Sequential enzymatic reactions for complex molecule synthesis. Key Quote: “The single-enzyme cascade reactions as catalysed by aldolases have been further expanded to multi-enzyme cascade processes, for instance in the synthesis of 2’-deoxyinosine in vitro or of complex molecules such as artemisinin or Taxol in vivo.”
11. Bioinformatics & Sequence Analysis
Definition: Computational tools for enzyme discovery and engineering. Key Quote: “Bioinformatics tools have become an integral part of modern protein engineering. Multiple sequence alignments across large enzyme families and homology searches have identified genes with similar catalytic activities.”
12. DNA Technologies
Definition: Gene synthesis, mutagenesis, and molecular cloning techniques. Key Quote: “Low-cost DNA synthesis has replaced isolation of genomic DNA as the starting point for protein engineering… Customized genes and even gene libraries are becoming commodity chemicals.”
13. Metabolic Engineering
Definition: Redesigning cellular pathways for biocatalytic production. Key Quote: “The method of disabling unwanted pathways to increase flux to the desired product is further developed by the third advance, metabolic pathway engineering.”
14. Computational Enzyme Design
Definition: Ab initio design of new enzymatic activities. Key Quote: “Computer design of new enzyme activities is not accurate. Design still requires testing 10–20 predictions and usually results in an enzyme with low activity.”
15. Process Integration
Definition: Incorporating biocatalysts into manufacturing processes. Key Quote: “In the past, an enzyme-based process was designed around the limitations of the enzyme; today, the enzyme is engineered to fit the process specifications.”
Historical Context (Three Waves)
First Wave (1900s+): Basic enzyme applications

Example: “Rosenthaler synthesized (R)-mandelonitrile from benzaldehyde and hydrogen cyanide using a plant extract”

Second Wave (1980s-1990s): Structure-based protein engineering

Example: “lipase-catalysed resolution of chiral precursors for synthesis of diltiazem”

Third Wave (1990s+): Directed evolution and advanced engineering

Example: “They pioneered molecular biology methods that rapidly and extensively modify biocatalysts via an in vitro version of Darwinian evolution”

Key Quantitative Achievements

Sitagliptin transaminase: 40,000-fold activity increase
Halohydrin dehalogenase: >4,000-fold rate improvement with 35 amino acid changes
Modern engineering: 30-40 amino acid substitutions typical (vs. 1-5 in early 2000s)
DNA sequencing cost: Decreased 1,000-fold from 70M to <10K (2002-2012)

backbone/core_reviews/summary/02_Sheldon.title: 02_Sheldon_2018_ChemRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/02_Sheldon.content:
Role of Biocatalysis in Sustainable Chemistry (Sheldon & Woodley, Chem. Rev. 2018)
Citation & scope
Programmatic review connecting green metrics and process design to practical biocatalysis: media (water/organic/scCO₂/ILs/DESs), biocatalysis engineering (protein, substrate, immobilization, reactor/ISR/flow), cascades, and bio-based economy use-cases.
Thesis / what’s new
Biocatalysis is intrinsically green & sustainable when engineered “by design”: pair directed evolution with medium/immobilization/reactor choices, quantify with E-factor/PMI/STY/TTN, and integrate in-line product removal and flow. The review ties choices to measurable impacts and gives actionable thresholds (e.g., target product concentration leaving reactor to tame downstream costs).
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Green metrics & sustainability — E-factor vs PMI (MI), simple vs complete E (incl. solvents/water), link to cost; complement with LCA/eco-efficiency tools (GREENSCOPE, FLASC).


Biocatalyst formats — flowsheets for resting whole cells, isolated enzymes, immobilized enzymes; format dictates flowsheet & recycle.


Media engineering — Water (push ≥50–300 g/L product to cap water removal); organic/biphasic; scCO₂ (31 °C, 7.4 MPa) for nonvolatile, high mass-transfer; ionic liquids (IL/PIL) & DES/NADES (choline-based) with design rules and DS options (e.g., scCO₂ extraction).


Protein & substrate engineering — evolution for activity/selectivity/stability; substrate engineering & promiscuity/chemomimetic leverage.


Biocatalyst engineering — Immobilization methods, CLEAs/CLECs, magnetic formats; reuse & stability vs mass-transfer.


Reactor/ISR/flow — packed beds, flow with in-situ/inline product removal (solvent swap, phase-split), design for high substrate loads and STY.


Cascades (cell-free synthetic biology) — linear/orthogonal with cofactor strategies; bridge to manufacturing.


Bio-based economy — starch & lignocellulose hydrolysis/pretreatment; food/beverage polysaccharide processing.


Key exemplars & metrics (for your tables)


Metrics in practice: E-factor correlates with API cost; simple vs complete E clarify solvent/water burdens; PMI = E+1; add EQ weightings and LCA indicators for fuller assessments.


Reactor/productivity rules: push outlet product concentration (≈ 50–300 g/L by product value tier) to trim water removal; higher substrate concentration ↓ E-factor (inverse correlation).


Solvent swap: concentrate by extracting from water into a lower-bp solvent before isolation (cost & green wins).


scCO₂ & IL/DES: lipase in scCO₂ improves rates vs hexane; PILs enable high-ee resolutions with minimal background; DES (ChCl/urea or glycerol) supports CaLB transesterifications amidations with toluene-like conversions; choline/sorbitol DES cut epoxidation E-factor 7.7 vs 16.7 in [BMIM][BF₄].


Industrial case (evolution + process): atorvastatin intermediate — evolved KRED/GDH/HHDH lifted TTN, STY (→25–28 g L⁻¹ h⁻¹), suppressed inhibition, and delivered overall E-factor 5.8 (excl. water); enzyme/cofactor waste <1%.


API route comparison: 7-ACA enzymatic vs chemical — enzymatic route wins on RME, energy and GHG, though used more water (higher E if water counted).


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Solvent/water burdens dominate PMI/E; predictive enzyme–IL compatibility still weak; need standardized reporting of process-relevant metrics; many comparisons confounded by maturity gap between routes.
Outlook
“Sustainable-by-design” = evolve catalysts to fit the process, not vice-versa; combine evolution + immobilization + ISR + flow; broaden task-specific IL/DES and scCO₂ strategies; embed metrics/LCA + economics early to steer toward low-PMI/high-STY routes.
Tags
Green metrics (E/PMI/LCA); cost correlation; product-concentration targets; water/organic/biphasic; scCO₂; IL/PIL/DES; immobilization/CLEAs/magnetic; evolution; ISR/flow; cascades; starch/lignocellulose; sustainable-by-design.
Biocatalysis Field Topics - From Sheldon & Woodley Review
Source: Sheldon, R.A. & Woodley, J.M. “Role of Biocatalysis in Sustainable Chemistry.” Chemical Reviews 118, 801-838 (2018).
Core Topics Identified
1. Sustainable Chemistry & Green Chemistry Principles
Definition: Framework for environmentally benign chemical processes using the 12 principles of green chemistry. Key Quote: “Green chemistry efficiently utilizes (preferably renewable) raw materials, eliminates waste and avoids the use of toxic and/or hazardous reagents and solvents in the manufacture and application of chemical products.”
2. Environmental Metrics & Life Cycle Assessment
Definition: Quantitative measures for assessing environmental impact of processes. Key Quote: “The E factor, in contrast, is the actual amount of waste produced in the process… Various alternative metrics have also been proposed for measuring the environmental footprints of processes.”
3. Alternative Reaction Media
Definition: Non-conventional solvents for biocatalytic reactions. Key Quote: “There is a growing interest, therefore, in the use of avant garde solvents such as ionic liquids (ILs) and deep eutectic solvents (DESs) for conducting enzymatic transformations.”
4. Ionic Liquids (ILs) for Biocatalysis
Definition: Room temperature molten salts as reaction media for enzymes. Key Quote: “ILs are biocompatible with many enzymes and are eminently suitable as alternative reaction media for biotransformations.”
5. Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs)
Definition: Eutectic mixtures of hydrogen bond donors and acceptors as green solvents. Key Quote: “DESs are produced by mixing ammonium or phosphonium salts with a hydrogen-bond donor… they are generally nontoxic and biodegradable.”
6. Protein Engineering for Industrial Applications
Definition: Enzyme optimization for commercial processes using directed evolution. Key Quote: “Today, it is eminently feasible to optimize enzymes to fit a predefined optimum process, that is, genuine benign by design.”
7. Substrate Engineering & Enzyme Promiscuity
Definition: Using enzymes with non-natural substrates and reactions. Key Quote: “Substrate engineering can lead to both the optimization of existing biocatalytic reactions and the invention of completely new transformations, which gave rise to the term enzyme promiscuity.”
8. Chemomimetic Biocatalysis
Definition: Creating semi-synthetic metalloenzymes for new reactions. Key Quote: “This chemomimetic biocatalysis strategy, in which a protein scaffold forms the starting point for modification, was successfully used to develop a semisynthetic peroxidase.”
9. Cross-Linked Enzyme Aggregates (CLEAs)
Definition: Carrier-free enzyme immobilization technology. Key Quote: “Cross-linking of these physical aggregates renders them permanently insoluble while maintaining their preorganized superstructure and, hence, their catalytic activity.”
10. Magnetic Enzyme Recovery Systems
Definition: Using magnetic nanoparticles for enzyme separation and reuse. Key Quote: “‘Smart’ ferromagnetic immobilized enzymes that can be easily separated magnetically on an industrial scale using standard commercial equipment.”
11. Reactor Engineering for Biocatalysis
Definition: Specialized reactor designs for enzymatic processes. Key Quote: “Chemical reactions used for commercial production need to be operated in an efficient manner with respect to starting material, catalyst, and equipment.”
12. In Situ Product Removal (ISPR)
Definition: Process intensification through integrated product separation. Key Quote: “One of the major limitations for the implementation of many biocatalytic processes is the low concentration of product leaving the reactor… in situ product removal (ISPR) can afford order-of-magnitude improvements in the process.”
13. Continuous Flow Biocatalysis
Definition: Flow chemistry techniques applied to enzymatic reactions. Key Quote: “The application of continuous-flow techniques can favorably influence the sustainability of manufacturing processes.”
14. Multi-Enzyme Cascade Reactions
Definition: Sequential enzymatic transformations in one-pot processes. Key Quote: “Biocatalytic cascade processes have become a particular focus of attention in recent years, motivated largely by potential environmental and economic benefits.”
15. Combi-CLEAs Technology
Definition: Co-immobilized multiple enzymes for cascade reactions. Key Quote: “The rates of biocatalytic cascades can be substantially increased by simulating the close proximity of the enzymes present in microbial cells… through the coimmobilization of two or more enzymes in a so-called combi-CLEA.”
16. Biobased Economy Applications
Definition: Using biocatalysis for converting renewable biomass to chemicals. Key Quote: “White biotechnology, with its underpinning tools of enzymes and microorganisms, is a key technological driver of this growing biobased economy.”
17. Lignocellulose Bioprocessing
Definition: Enzymatic conversion of cellulosic biomass to fermentable sugars. Key Quote: “The complex, recalcitrant structure of lignocellulose… requires the use of a complex cocktail of cellulolytic and hemicellulolytic enzymes, referred to collectively as cellulase.”
18. Process Integration & Manufacturing
Definition: Incorporating biocatalytic steps into chemical manufacturing. Key Quote: “An essential step in enabling the further implementation of biocatalysis into common industrial practice is its integration into the broader synthesis and manufacturing context.”
Key Industrial Examples
Atorvastatin Process: Three-enzyme cascade (KRED + GDH + HHDH)

Quote: “Assessment of this process according to the metrics and 12 principles of green chemistry clearly showed that it is substantially greener than previous processes.”

Sitagliptin Synthesis: Engineered transaminase replacing metal catalysis

Quote: “The biocatalytic process not only reduced the total waste and eliminated all transition metals, but increased the overall yield and the productivity by 53%.”

Quantitative Sustainability Metrics

E-factor: kg waste per kg product
Process Mass Intensity (PMI): Total mass used per mass of product
Atom Economy: Theoretical efficiency of atom utilization
Life Cycle Assessment (LCA): Cradle-to-grave environmental impact

Future Challenges Highlighted

Product Concentration: Need for >50-300 g/L depending on product value
Cofactor Recycling: Sustainable regeneration systems required
Process Development Speed: Faster methods needed for industrial adoption
Multidisciplinary Integration: Bridging chemistry, biology, and engineering

backbone/core_reviews/summary/03_Bell_20.title: 03_Bell_2021_NatureMethodsPrimers
backbone/core_reviews/summary/03_Bell_20.content:
Biocatalysis (Primer) (Bell et al., Nat. Rev. Methods Primers 2021)
Citation & scope
A methods-primer that walks the end-to-end pipeline: route design (manual & CASP/RetroBioCat), biocatalyst sourcing (commercial kits, biosynthetic enzymes, metagenomes, in-silico mining), optimization (directed evolution, computation, ncAAs), cascade build (design–build–optimize), and bioprocess metrics/implementation.
Thesis / what’s new
Biocatalysis is mainstream because discovery (databases, gene synthesis), laboratory evolution, and computational design now deliver tailored enzymes fast; standardized data/ontologies and reporting are emerging, while bio-retrosynthesis and CASP tools make de-novo cascades practical (e.g., islatravir).
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Route design & tools — Manual + RetroBioCat for bio-retrosynthesis; iterate reaction design ⇄ enzyme choice ⇄ bioprocess.


Sources of biocatalysts — (a) Commercial libraries (KREDs, IREDs, TAs, BVMOs, MAO-N, lyases), (b) biosynthetic enzymes (e.g., Fe(II)/α-KG hydroxylases/halogenases), (c) metagenomic & in-silico mining; rapid gene synthesis makes any reported sequence accessible.


Directed evolution — Focused libraries (CAST/ISM, reduced codons) and high-throughput screens (plates, colony colorimetry, FADS/AADS droplets, displays, continuous evolution) are the workhorse.


Computational design — Theozyme→Rosetta, multistate/MD-guided designs, tunnel analysis (CAVER), FRESCO stabilization; dynamics/allostery and distal mutations matter.


Genetic code expansion (ncAAs) — Install new functional groups; evolve aaRS; demonstrated de-novo hydrolase OE1→OE1.3 with >9,000-fold rate boost vs free Me-His.


Cascade development — Design–Build–Optimize loop; linear/orthogonal/cyclic topologies; in-vitro, in-vivo, or hybrid; cofactor, compatibility, immobilization, ISR considered up-front.


What makes a good industrial biocatalyst — High activity at high loads, solvent/pH/temperature tolerance, operational stability (TTN), immobilizability, and strong green/economic metrics (PMI, E-factor, productivity).


Standards & infrastructure — Data/metadata, STRENDA, SiLA/AnIML, enzyme repositories; Revenant for ancestral proteins; IP/FTO awareness.


Key exemplars & metrics


Acrylamide (NHase): 50–100 g·L⁻¹·h⁻¹ productivities at 300–500 g·L⁻¹ titers; a flagship whole-cell process.


Sitagliptin (TA): substrate walking + evolution → 200 g·L⁻¹ load, 45 °C, 50% DMSO, >99.9% ee; beats Rh catalysis on cost/green metrics.


Islatravir: 9-enzyme cascade (5 evolved) with ATP/phosphate shuttling; high overall yield without workups.


IREDs: pilot-scale 13 g·L⁻¹·h⁻¹; engineered IRED for GSK2879552 shows 38,000× turnover gain vs WT.


(–)-Ambrox (SHC): whole-cell cyclization, ~12 g·L⁻¹·h⁻¹ after DoE optimization.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
ML/design still limited by data quality/metadata; screening modality biases (e.g., fluorescence only in droplets); scale logistics for cofactors; broad, oxidative C–C coupling remains challenging; need consistent reporting of process-relevant metrics.
Outlook
Expect tighter automation + standards, bigger public enzyme libraries, expanded ncAA and de-novo platforms, and increasingly routine designer cascades bridging biocatalysis and biotransformations for complex targets.
Tags
Route design & RetroBioCat; commercial & biosynthetic enzyme sources; metagenomics/in-silico; directed evolution (FADS/AADS/continuous); computation (Rosetta/FRESCO/CAVER); ncAAs; cascades (DBO loop); industrial metrics (PMI/E-factor/STY); standards (STRENDA, SiLA/AnIML).
Biocatalysis Field Topics - From Bell et al. Nature Methods Primers 2021
Document ID: Bell_2021_NatureMethodsPrimers
Core Topics Extracted:
1. Commercial Enzyme Sources & Libraries

Definition: Ready-made enzyme collections from vendors for direct screening
Key aspects: KRED libraries, IRED libraries, transaminase collections, oxidoreductase panels
Applications: Rapid biocatalyst identification, substrate-specific screening

2. Natural Product Biosynthetic Enzymes

Definition: Enzymes from specialized metabolite pathways repurposed for synthesis
Key aspects: Fe(II)/2-oxoglutarate dependent enzymes, halogenases, methyltransferases
Applications: C-H functionalization, stereoselective transformations

3. Metagenomic & In Silico Enzyme Mining

Definition: Discovery of new biocatalysts from environmental DNA and sequence databases
Key aspects: Function-based screening, sequence-based screening, degenerate primers
Applications: Novel enzyme discovery, extreme environment adaptation

4. High-Throughput Screening Platforms

Definition: Automated systems for rapid evaluation of enzyme variants
Key aspects: Microfluidics, droplet sorting, fluorescence-activated screening
Applications: Directed evolution campaigns, library screening

5. DNA Library Generation Strategies

Definition: Methods for creating genetic diversity in protein engineering
Key aspects: Error-prone PCR, saturation mutagenesis, DNA shuffling, CAST
Applications: Focused evolution, combinatorial optimization

6. Computational Enzyme Design

Definition: Computer-aided approaches for rational enzyme engineering
Key aspects: Rosetta design, molecular dynamics, QM/MM calculations, CASCO
Applications: Active site redesign, stability enhancement

7. Machine Learning in Protein Engineering

Definition: AI-guided approaches for predicting beneficial mutations
Key aspects: Sequence-function relationships, predictive modeling, smart libraries
Applications: Reducing screening burden, accelerating optimization

8. Non-Canonical Amino Acid Incorporation

Definition: Expanding the chemical alphabet of proteins beyond 20 natural amino acids
Key aspects: Orthogonal tRNA synthetases, genetic code expansion, novel chemistries
Applications: New catalytic mechanisms, enhanced stability

9. Enzyme Cascade Design & Development

Definition: Multi-step biocatalytic processes in single reaction vessels
Key aspects: Linear cascades, orthogonal cascades, cyclic cascades, retrobiosynthesis
Applications: Complex molecule synthesis, telescoped processes

10. Computer-Aided Synthesis Planning (CASP)

Definition: Automated tools for designing biocatalytic routes
Key aspects: RetroBioCat, pathway prediction, enzyme database integration
Applications: Route design, cascade planning

11. Bioprocess Development & Scale-Up

Definition: Translation from lab-scale to industrial manufacturing
Key aspects: Fed-batch strategies, ISPR, continuous processing, immobilization
Applications: Industrial implementation, cost optimization

12. Industrial Process Metrics

Definition: Quantitative measures for evaluating biocatalytic processes
Key aspects: Productivity (g/L/h), E-factor, atom economy, process mass intensity
Applications: Sustainability assessment, process comparison

13. Enzyme Immobilization Technologies

Definition: Methods for binding enzymes to solid supports for reuse
Key aspects: CLEAs, carrier-bound enzymes, flow systems, operational stability
Applications: Continuous processing, enzyme recovery

14. Ultra-High-Throughput Methods

Definition: Screening technologies capable of >10^6 variants
Key aspects: Droplet microfluidics, FACS, continuous evolution, selection-based approaches
Applications: Massive library screening, rare variant discovery

15. Biocatalyst Databases & Data Management

Definition: Repositories for storing and accessing enzyme data
Key aspects: Substrate specificity, reaction conditions, BioCatNet, PrenDB
Applications: Enzyme selection, knowledge sharing

16. Cell-Free Protein Expression

Definition: In vitro systems for rapid enzyme production without cells
Key aspects: Reduced cycle times, direct enzyme access, high-throughput compatible
Applications: Accelerated development, prototyping

17. Continuous Flow Biocatalysis

Definition: Steady-state enzymatic processes in flow reactors
Key aspects: Immobilized enzymes, residence time control, process intensification
Applications: Industrial manufacturing, multi-step synthesis

18. Biocatalytic Late-Stage Functionalization

Definition: Enzyme-catalyzed modifications of complex molecules
Key aspects: C-H activation, selective oxidation, site-specific modification
Applications: Pharmaceutical diversification, compound libraries

19. Green Chemistry Metrics in Biocatalysis

Definition: Environmental impact assessment of enzymatic processes
Key aspects: Carbon footprint, waste reduction, renewable feedstocks
Applications: Sustainability evaluation, process optimization

20. Reproducibility Standards (STRENDA)

Definition: Guidelines for standardized reporting of enzyme data
Key aspects: Experimental conditions, kinetic parameters, data validation
Applications: Data quality, cross-study comparisons

Key Methodological Focus Areas:
Advanced Screening Technologies

Microfluidics and droplet sorting
Mass spectrometry coupling
Label-free detection methods
Ultra-high-throughput platforms

Computational Tools

Protein structure prediction
Molecular dynamics simulations
Machine learning integration
Automated design workflows

Industrial Translation

Scale-up considerations
Process economics
Regulatory compliance
Intellectual property management

Backbone Categories


Route & Reaction Design — bio-retrosynthesis/CASP tools (e.g., RetroBioCat), manual planning.


Enzyme Sourcing & Discovery — commercial kits, natural-product biosynthesis enzymes, metagenomic & in-silico mining.


Protein Engineering (Directed Evolution) — focused libraries, ISM/CASTing, reduced codons, recombination.


Computational Design — Rosetta/QM/MM/EVB, conformational dynamics, multistate design, FRESCO/CASCO.


Genetic Code Expansion (ncAA) — orthogonal aaRS/tRNA, mechanistic probes, new catalytic motifs.


Screening & Selection Platforms — plate/LC assays, colony colorimetric, microfluidics/FADS, phage display, continuous evolution.


Cascades & Pathway Assembly — design–build–optimize cycles; in vitro / in vivo / hybrid implementations.


Cofactors & Compatibility — cofactor needs/regen, solvent and pH tolerance, high-load operation considerations.


Immobilization & Operational Stability — reuse, lifetime, flow readiness, ISPR interfaces.


Process & Reactor Engineering — fed-batch, two-phase/solvent systems, analytics/automation, scale-up.


Metrics, Economics & Sustainability — productivity (g L⁻¹ h⁻¹), turnover/TTN, E-factor/PMI/C-factor, robustness targets.


Applications & Case Studies — pharma/fine chems/materials; exemplar cascades (e.g., islatravir), FTO/IP notes.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/04_Winkler.title: 04_Winkler_2021_ACSCentralScience
backbone/core_reviews/summary/04_Winkler.content:
Power of Biocatalysis for Organic Synthesis (Winkler, Schrittwieser, Kroutil, ACS Cent. Sci. 2021)
Citation & scope
Tutorial/overview arguing that enzymes are now a mainstream toolbox for organic synthesis, detailing how active-site 3D confinement + dynamics give high chemo/regio/enantioselectivity; tours core reaction classes, new-to-nature reactivity, and cascades (industrial case studies included).
Thesis / what’s new
Emphasizes enzymes as “high-tech catalysts”: precise substrate positioning (≥3 interactions), gated tunnels, conformational dynamics/allostery, and synergistic residues across shells; stability can be engineered (ancestral reconstruction, salt bridges, disulfides, glycosylation). Modern routes mix single-step biotransformations with multi-enzyme cascades, and evolution/computation keep expanding scope into abiological reactions.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


How enzymes achieve selectivity — binding/activation/TS stabilization/product release; tunnel gating & backbone motion; trade-off between scope and selectivity; libraries + evolution to tune both.


Established transformations — hydrolases (kinetic/DKR of esters/amides), ADHs (ketone/aldehyde → alcohol), TAs / IREDs / RedAms / AmDHs (amines), OYEs, CARs, P450s/monooxygenases, peroxygenases, halogenases; compact “menu” in Table 2.


New-to-nature catalysis — reaction promiscuity (e.g., 4-oxalocrotonate tautomerase organocatalyst-like chemistry), photo-biocatalysis with flavin EREDs (radical pathways), engineered P450→P411 for carbene/nitrene transfer (C–C, C–H amination), and artificial metalloenzymes (streptavidin–biotin “Suzukiase”).


Cascades — enzymes’ operational compatibility enables one-pot, equilibrium-driven sequences; showpieces include atorvastatin intermediate and islatravir.


Process & pedagogy — productivity/stability still limiters; call for bigger, public enzyme libraries, repositories, and ML-assisted design; integrate biocatalysis into chem curricula.


Key exemplars & metrics


Pregabalin route: lipase kinetic resolution → E-factor 86 → 17 vs 1st-gen process (waste ↓5×).


Atorvastatin intermediate (ADH reduction + HHDH): 95% isolated yield, >99.9% ee, STY 480 g·L⁻¹·d⁻¹ after enzyme evolution/cofactor engineering.


Sitagliptin TA: “substrate walking” over 11 rounds, 27 mutations → 275 g·L⁻¹ substrate, 88% isolated yield, >99.95% ee; productivity +56%, waste −19% vs Rh/Josiphos route.


Islatravir cascade: 9 enzymes (5 evolved), no workups, 51% overall yield; design uses oxidation → phosphorylation → aldol assembly + phosphate shuttling/ATP recycling to bias equilibria.


New bonds: engineered P450/P411 for cyclopropanation and C–H amination (high ee, nitrene transfer); Rma cyt c and Suzukiase illustrate heme and hybrid scaffolds enabling abiological steps.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Catalyst stability/lifetime dictates STY; development time/costs still high; broader C–C coupling (esp. oxidative) remains a frontier; predictive design of dynamics/distal mutations and scalable SAM/ATP cofactor logistics are pain points.
Outlook
Expect larger ready-to-use enzyme libraries, repository distribution, and increasing ML-guided design; more tight, active-site-controlled transformations (including oxidative C–C) and hybrid catalysts will further compress routes; biocatalysis education is pivotal for adoption.
Tags
Active-site confinement & dynamics; hydrolases/ADHs/TAs/IREDs/RedAms/AmDHs; CARs/OYEs; P450/peroxygenase/halogenase; photo-biocatalysis; P411 carbene/nitrene; artificial metalloenzymes (Suzukiase); cascades (atorvastatin, islatravir); E-factor/STY; libraries & repositories; ML & education.

The paper serves as an excellent bridge between enzymology and synthetic organic chemistry, providing mechanistic depth while maintaining focus on practical applications.
Categories


Need for a broad (chiral) catalyst toolbox — motivation, green-chemistry drivers, early industrial examples.


Enzymes as an extension of the catalyst toolbox — what “biocatalyst” means in practice (crude, purified, immobilized; secretion), circular-economy angle.


High-tech features of enzymes — catalytic cycle (binding/activation/TS stabilization/release), active-site architecture, tunnels, dynamics/allostery, cofactors.


Developing a unique biocatalyst for a specific reaction — selectivity vs scope trade-off; libraries; protein engineering; computational routes.


Established single-step biotransformations: hydrolases — lipases/esterases for (dynamic) kinetic resolutions; pregabalin case.


Established single-step biotransformations: ADHs — stereoselective reductions with cofactor recycling; atorvastatin intermediate example.


Established single-step biotransformations: amine formation — TAs, IREDs/RedAms, AmDHs; sitagliptin (engineered TA) route.


Catalogue of additional reactions (Table 2) — C–C bond forming/cleaving enzymes, hydroxylations, Baeyer–Villiger, halogenases, CARs, methyltransferases, etc.


Reactions new to nature (enzyme promiscuity) — e.g., 4-oxalocrotonate tautomerase chemistry; general promiscuity concept.


Photobiocatalysis enabling radical chemistry — light-activated ERED reactivity for cyclizations/intermolecular C–C formation.


Engineered heme enzymes for abiological transformations — P450/P411 carbene and nitrene transfers (cyclopropanation, C–H amination).


Protein–small-molecule hybrids — streptavidin–biotin “Suzukiase” and related hybrid catalysts.


Multienzyme one-pot cascades — principles and the islatravir nine-enzyme case study.


Future & implementation needs — stability/lifetime & STY, faster/cheaper development, education, open libraries/repositories, ML/design outlook; gaps (e.g., oxidative C–C coupling).


Winkler_2021_ACS_CentSci — Higher-order categories


Why biocatalysis now (green-chemistry drivers & synthesis gaps). Motivation for routes that are cleaner, scalable, and cost-effective.


Enzymes as precision catalysts. Active-site control, confined-space effects, dynamics/allostery — why enzymes deliver chemo/region/stereoselectivity.


The “biocatalyst toolbox” for synthesis. Workhorse enzymatic transformations as a general category (hydrolysis, redox, C–C/CH-functionalization) rather than enumerated reactions.


Tailoring catalysts (engineering & selection). Using directed evolution/rational design to tune scope, activity, and selectivity for target reactions.


New-to-nature reactivity from enzyme promiscuity. Expanding beyond native function (e.g., engineered heme proteins for carbene/nitrene transfer).


Photobiocatalysis as a radical-chemistry bridge. Light-enabled enzyme reactivity opening new bond-forming logic.


Chemo–bio hybrids (protein-hosted small-molecule/metal catalysis). Artificial metalloenzymes and protein-embedded organocatalysts as a general platform.


Multienzyme cascades & telescoped routes. One-pot/linear cascades for step-economic synthesis; showcased by the islatravir case.


Process performance & implementation metrics. Emphasis that productivity metrics (e.g., STY) matter when translating to synthesis.


Outlook: diversification, design, ML & training. Field needs: broader enzyme repertoires, computational/ML design, and integrating biocatalysis into chem curricula.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/05_Reetz_2.title: 05_Reetz_2013_JACS
backbone/core_reviews/summary/05_Reetz_2.content:
Biocatalysis in Organic Chemistry and Biotechnology: Past, Present, and Future (Manfred T. Reetz, JACS 2013)
Citation & scope
Perspective tracing biocatalysis from early milestones to modern directed evolution, with emphasis on semirational methods (CAST/ISM), library statistics (reduced alphabets), industrial case studies, in-vitro cascades, and metabolic engineering.
Thesis / what’s new
Two historic blockers—enzyme availability and low scope/selectivity/stability—were solved by recombinant DNA and directed evolution. Systematic strategies (CAST/ISM + reduced alphabets) turn enzymes into process-grade catalysts; in-vitro cascades and engineered pathways expand what enzymes can make.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


History & enablers — Pasteur→Fischer→Buchner; rise of recombinant DNA and PCR enabling enzyme supply.


Industrial landscape — From fine chems to bulk (e.g., acrylamide via NHase 4×10⁵ t/yr; nicotinamide 6×10³ t/yr).


Classical limitations — insufficient stereo-/regioselectivity, narrow scope, poor stability, product inhibition.


Directed evolution toolbox — epPCR, saturation mutagenesis, DNA shuffling; shift to semirational (CAST, ISM) guided by structure and statistics.


Library quality & statistics — Reduced alphabets (NDT vs NNK), oversampling rules, CASTER design aid; cooperativity and pathway fitness landscapes; escaping local minima.


Process metrics & screening — HT ee assays (UV/MS/GC/HPLC); screening remains bottleneck; selections desirable but rare.


Cascades & pathways — In-vitro enzyme cascades (e.g., B12 precursor, 12 enzymes/17 steps); metabolic engineering (e.g., artemisinic acid → artemisinin semi-synthesis).


Key exemplars & metrics


ISM case (lipase, kinetic resolution): pathway B→A gave E = 594 (S) with only ~10k screens vs ~50k previously; revealed strong mutational cooperativity.


Industrial nitrilase (Lipitor intermediate): saturation mutagenesis across 330 positions; at 3 M substrate, 96% conversion, 98.5% ee—also solved product inhibition.


MAO-N deracemization of amines: robust route to R/S amines incl. 2°/3°; commercialized; complements lipase DKR.


Large-scale biocatalysis: NHase to acrylamide (4×10⁵ t/yr), nitrile hydration to nicotinamide (6×10³ t/yr).


Fitness landscapes: 24-pathway ISM study—16 monotonic paths; 8 with local minima navigable by choosing inferior templates (escape via “neutral drift”).


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Screening throughput and general selection schemes for stereo/regio remain limited; predictive design of distal mutation effects is immature; activity of promiscuous/de-novo catalysts still low without evolution.
Outlook
Broader adoption of semirational evolution (CAST/ISM + reduced alphabets), deeper mechanistic/theory to explain cooperativity, growth of in-vitro cascades and designer cells, and closer chemo-bio retrosynthesis integration for complex targets.
Tags
History & enabling tech; directed evolution; CAST/ISM; reduced alphabets (NDT); cooperativity & fitness landscapes; screening/selection; industrial NHase & MAO-N; in-vitro cascades; metabolic engineering; artemisinic acid; B12 pathway.

Biocatalysis Field Topics - From Reetz JACS 2013
Document ID: Reetz_2013_JACS
Core Topics Extracted:
1. Historical Milestones in Biocatalysis

Definition: Key developmental moments that shaped the field from Pasteur’s 1858 kinetic resolution to modern applications
Examples: Pasteur’s tartaric acid resolution, Fischer’s lock-and-key hypothesis, Buchner’s cell-free fermentation
Significance: Foundational discoveries that established biocatalysis principles

2. Recombinant DNA Technology Revolution

Definition: Breakthrough in the late 1970s enabling enzyme overexpression in heterologous hosts
Applications: Large-scale enzyme production, access to previously unavailable enzymes
Impact: Solved the fundamental problem of enzyme availability for practical applications

3. Traditional Enzyme Limitations

Definition: Historical constraints that limited enzyme utility in synthetic chemistry
Issues: Poor stereoselectivity, narrow substrate scope, insufficient stability, product inhibition
Significance: Challenges that directed evolution was developed to address

4. Error-Prone PCR (epPCR)

Definition: Random mutagenesis method targeting entire genes for evolutionary improvement
Mechanism: Low-fidelity DNA replication introduces random mutations across protein sequence
Applications: Thermostability enhancement, activity improvement, first directed evolution studies

5. Saturation Mutagenesis & CASTing

Definition: Systematic randomization at predetermined sites near enzyme active sites
Strategy: Combinatorial Active-Site Saturation Test (CAST) focusing on binding pocket residues
Advantages: More focused libraries requiring less screening than random methods

6. DNA Shuffling Technology

Definition: Recombination method mixing beneficial mutations from different variants
Process: Gene fragmentation followed by reassembly creates hybrid sequences
Benefits: Combines advantageous mutations while removing deleterious ones

7. Iterative Saturation Mutagenesis (ISM)

Definition: Systematic multi-round approach visiting different binding pocket sites sequentially
Strategy: Sequential optimization of 2-4 sites using multiple evolutionary pathways
Innovation: Highly efficient method requiring minimal screening for maximum improvement

8. High-Throughput Screening Systems

Definition: Automated methods for rapidly assaying thousands of enzyme variants
Technologies: UV/vis plate readers, multiplexed MS, automated GC/HPLC, fluorescence assays
Bottleneck: Screening remains the limiting factor in directed evolution efficiency

9. Cooperative Mutational Effects

Definition: Non-additive interactions between mutations producing synergistic improvements
Discovery: Systematic deconvolution reveals mutations work better together than alone
Importance: Explains why ISM and saturation mutagenesis outperform random approaches

10. Fitness Landscape Navigation

Definition: Understanding evolutionary pathways through mutational space toward improved variants
Challenges: Local minima can trap evolution; escape strategies involve accepting inferior mutants
Insights: Multiple pathways exist to reach improved variants; cooperative effects dominate

11. Industrial Directed Evolution Applications

Definition: Commercial implementations of laboratory evolution for biocatalyst improvement
Examples: Nitrilase for Lipitor intermediate, monoamine oxidase for chiral amines, transaminase for sitagliptin
Impact: Demonstrates practical value and economic viability of evolved biocatalysts

12. Reduced Amino Acid Alphabets

Definition: Using smaller sets of amino acids in saturation mutagenesis to improve library quality
Strategy: NDT codon degeneracy (12 amino acids) versus NNK (20 amino acids)
Benefits: Higher hit rates, superior performance, reduced screening requirements

13. Enzyme Promiscuity Engineering

Definition: Developing enzymes capable of catalyzing non-natural reaction types
Approaches: Hybrid catalysts, artificial metalloenzymes, computational design
Limitations: Activity typically much lower than natural enzymes; ongoing challenge

14. QM/MM Computational Analysis

Definition: Quantum mechanical/molecular mechanical modeling to understand evolutionary improvements
Applications: Explaining stereoselectivity origins, predicting beneficial mutations
Value: Provides molecular-level understanding of how mutations improve catalytic properties

15. Multi-Enzyme Cascade Reactions

Definition: Sequential transformations using enzyme mixtures in single reaction vessels
Advantages: Chemical compatibility, orthogonal selectivities, simplified workup
Applications: Complex natural product synthesis, vitamin B12 precursor production

16. Metabolic Pathway Engineering

Definition: Manipulating cellular systems to produce desired compounds through engineered biosynthetic routes
Scope: Both simple compounds (biofuels) and complex natural products (pharmaceuticals)
Example: Artemisinin production via engineered artemisinic acid pathway

17. Protein Thermostability Enhancement

Definition: Improving enzyme resistance to heat and denaturing conditions
Methods: B-FIT strategy targeting high B-factor residues, rational design approaches
Importance: Essential for industrial applications requiring harsh operating conditions

18. Biocatalytic Retrosynthesis

Definition: Strategic planning incorporating both enzymes and chemical catalysts in synthetic routes
Integration: Guidelines for combining biocatalytic and chemocatalytic steps effectively
Emergence: New paradigm enabled by reliable enzyme engineering methods

19. Library Quality Optimization

Definition: Strategies to create smaller, higher-quality mutant libraries requiring less screening
Approaches: Statistical sampling, pooling techniques, Quick Quality Control (QQC)
Goal: Achieve improvements with libraries of 2000-3000 variants using standard analytical methods

20. Deconvolution & Mechanistic Studies

Definition: Systematic analysis of individual mutations to understand their contributions
Methods: Single mutation analysis, fitness landscape construction, structural studies
Value: Reveals cooperative effects, eliminates superfluous mutations, guides future engineering


Review Character: Comprehensive historical perspective covering the entire evolution of biocatalysis from early discoveries through modern directed evolution techniques.
Unique Contributions: Detailed analysis of directed evolution methodologies, extensive ISM development, fitness landscape concepts, and integration of computational approaches.
Key Insights: Emphasizes the transformative impact of directed evolution in solving traditional enzyme limitations and the importance of cooperative mutational effects in protein engineering.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/06_Arnold_.title: 06_Arnold_2018_Angew
backbone/core_reviews/summary/06_Arnold_.content:
Directed Evolution: Bringing New Chemistry to Life (Frances H. Arnold, Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2018)
Citation & scope
Perspective on directed evolution as a forward-engineering method that turns enzymes into catalysts for abiological reactions and even new bond formations (C–Si, C–B), with heme proteins as a major platform.
Thesis / what’s new
Evolution in the lab—mutate ➜ screen ➜ recombine—circumvents sequence–function ignorance and reliably upgrades activity, selectivity, and stability; starting from promiscuous low-level activities and using non-natural reagents unlocks reactions unknown to nature or hard for small-molecule catalysis.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Evolution as engineering: iterative mutation/selection outperforms design for complex traits; beneficial mutations often lie far from the active site.


Promiscuity → novelty: mine trace activities and evolve them into useful catalysis (e.g., carbene/nitrene transfer).


Heme proteins as platforms: especially P450/P411 and small cyt c scaffolds; Cys→Ser axial ligand switch yields P411 (CO band 411 nm), suppressing monooxygenase while promoting carbene/nitrene chemistry.


Whole-cell catalysis for new bonds: expression in E. coli enables gram-scale biogenesis of organosilicon and organoborane products.


Pushing mechanism space: evolved enzymes enforce stepwise pathways (e.g., anti-Markovnikov oxidation via radical/cation & 1,2-hydride migration) that outcompete favored concerted routes of small-molecule catalysis.


Key exemplars & metrics


Olefin cyclopropanation (carbene transfer): evolved heme proteins deliver pharma precursors (e.g., levomilnacipran, ticagrelor intermediate) with high diastereo/enantioselectivity, in water/whole cells.


Intermolecular benzylic C–H amination: P411CHA shows hundreds of turnovers with >99% ee—a long-standing challenge for small-molecule catalysis.


Carbene insertion into Si–H (C–Si bonds): evolved Rhodothermus marinus cyt c variants reach up to 8,200 TTN and >99% ee across diverse silanes.


Carbene insertion into B–H (C–B bonds): evolved Rma cyt c delivers up to 15,300 turnovers, 99:1 e.r., 100% chemoselectivity; works in E. coli and is gram-scale ready.


Anti-Markovnikov oxygenase (aMOx): engineered P450 performs thousands of turnovers to give enantioselective anti-Markovnikov carbonyls; 12 mutations scattered throughout the protein control a stepwise pathway; couples with ADH for redox hydration with NADPH recycling.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
We still poorly predict distal mutation effects and can’t yet design such activities from first principles; de-novo designs remain weak starters that benefit from subsequent evolution.
Outlook (authors)
Treat enzymes as DNA-encoded, evolvable, chiral TM complexes; expect continued expansion into reactions unknown to biology or synthetic chemistry, with DNA-programmable microbes producing a broader palette of chemicals.
Tags
Directed evolution; promiscuity seeding; P450→P411; carbene & nitrene transfer; C–Si/C–B bond formation; aMOx anti-Markovnikov oxidation; whole-cell new-bond synthesis; distal mutations; TTN/ee.
Biocatalysis Field Topics - From Arnold Angewandte Chemie 2018
Document ID: Arnold_2018_Angew
Core Topics Extracted:
1. Evolution as Innovation Algorithm

Definition: Applying biological evolution principles as a forward-engineering process for catalyst optimization
Mechanism: Mutation, selection, and reproduction cycles to solve complex optimization problems
Advantages: Circumvents ignorance of sequence-function relationships through empirical improvement

2. DNA-Programmable Chemical Synthesis

Definition: Vision of microorganisms engineered to produce chemicals through programmed biosynthetic pathways
Applications: Sustainable chemical industry using renewable resources and earth-abundant materials
Impact: Alternative to petroleum-based synthetic chemistry with improved efficiency and selectivity

3. Limitations of Rational Protein Design

Definition: Why structure-based design fails to reliably predict performance-enhancing mutations
Reality: Understanding of sequence-function relationships lags behind desires for new enzymes
Solution: Directed evolution bypasses design limitations through empirical optimization

4. Promiscuous Enzymatic Activities

Definition: Low-level side activities in enzymes that serve as starting points for evolution
Importance: Innovation building blocks already present in existing proteins
Strategy: Identifying and enhancing latent capabilities rather than creating from scratch

5. Heme Protein Engineering Platform

Definition: Cytochrome P450s and related heme proteins as versatile scaffolds for new chemistry
Rationale: Natural diversity in P450 functions suggests evolvability for additional reactions
Success: Most successful protein family for engineering non-natural activities

6. Carbene Transfer Reactions

Definition: Engineering enzymes to catalyze carbene-mediated cyclopropanation reactions unknown in biology
Discovery: Heme proteins can form reactive carbenes from diazo precursors in aqueous conditions
Applications: Synthesis of chiral pharmaceutical precursors (levomilnacipran, ticagrelor)

7. Nitrene Transfer Chemistry

Definition: Development of enzymes for C-H amination and aziridination using nitrene intermediates
Innovation: P411 variants with altered heme coordination promoting nitrene-transfer activities
Breakthrough: Intermolecular C(sp3)-H amination with excellent enantioselectivity (>99% ee)

8. P411 Engineering Strategy

Definition: Systematic replacement of conserved P450 cysteine ligand with serine to create new reactivities
Effect: Abolishes native monooxygenase activity while promoting carbene/nitrene transfer
Advantage: Shifts enzyme preference toward non-natural reaction pathways

9. Carbon-Silicon Bond Formation

Definition: First biological enzymes capable of forming C-Si bonds through carbene insertion
Significance: Accessing organosilicon chemistry with biological catalysts
Performance: High enantioselectivity (>99% ee) and thousands of turnovers for pharmaceutical intermediates

10. Carbon-Boron Bond Formation

Definition: Engineering enzymes for C-B bond formation, creating bonds completely unknown in biology
Achievement: Chiral organoborane synthesis with 15,300 turnovers and 99:1 enantiomeric ratios
Impact: Opens new chemical space for biological systems using earth-abundant boron

11. Anti-Markovnikov Oxygenase (aMOx)

Definition: Novel enzyme mechanism for converting alkenes to anti-Markovnikov carbonyl compounds
Innovation: Exploiting stepwise radical mechanism over favored concerted epoxidation pathway
Uniqueness: First enantioselective method for this transformation, impossible with small-molecule catalysts

12. Abiological Bond Formation

Definition: Creating enzymes that form chemical bonds never found in natural biological systems
Examples: C-Si, C-B bonds representing entirely new chemical space for biology
Approach: Using non-natural reagents with evolved protein scaffolds

13. Macromolecular Catalyst Advantages

Definition: Unique capabilities of protein active sites compared to small-molecule catalysts
Benefits: Precise substrate orientation, competing pathway suppression, reactive intermediate stabilization
Applications: Reactions requiring control over multiple competing pathways

14. Enzyme-Chemical Catalyst Integration

Definition: Coupling evolved enzymes with traditional chemical catalysts for enhanced synthetic utility
Example: aMOx combined with alcohol dehydrogenase for anti-Markovnikov alkene hydration
Benefit: Expands synthetic accessibility while maintaining enzymatic advantages

15. Stepwise vs Concerted Reaction Control

Definition: Engineering enzymes to favor kinetically disfavored stepwise mechanisms over thermodynamically favored pathways
Mechanism: Protein environment stabilizes radical intermediates and controls selectivity
Impact: Accessing chemistry impossible with conventional catalysts

16. Beneficial Mutations Beyond Active Sites

Definition: Discovery that performance-enhancing mutations often occur far from catalytic centers
Observation: Surface mutations and distant residues significantly impact catalytic properties
Implication: Protein architecture globally influences catalytic function in unpredictable ways

17. Chemical Intuition in Enzyme Engineering

Definition: Importance of understanding synthetic chemistry to guide enzyme evolution projects
Requirements: Knowing right reagents, conditions, and reactions to test with appropriate enzymes
Success Factor: Combining biological engineering expertise with chemical knowledge

18. Protein Evolvability Principles

Definition: Why natural proteins are readily adaptable to new functions through mutation
Basis: Products of evolution retain evolutionary potential and structural flexibility
Evidence: Ease of finding beneficial mutations with appropriate screening strategies

19. Laboratory vs Natural Evolution

Definition: Advantages of controlled laboratory evolution over natural selection
Benefits: Directed selection pressure, rapid cycles, focus on human-relevant properties
Speed: Achieving evolution in months that might take nature millions of years

20. Future Chemical Space Exploration

Definition: Vision for discovering what enzymes CAN do beyond their natural functions
Philosophy: Shifting from “what do enzymes do?” to “what CAN they do?”
Potential: Vast unexplored catalytic capabilities waiting to be unlocked through evolution


Review Character: Nobel Laureate’s personal perspective on directed evolution’s transformative impact, focusing on breakthrough achievements in creating entirely new chemistry.
Unique Contributions: First-hand account of pioneering work in abiological chemistry, detailed examples of C-Si and C-B bond formation, philosophical framework for enzyme engineering.
Key Insights: Emphasizes evolution as innovation algorithm, demonstrates protein versatility beyond natural functions, shows path to sustainable chemical industry through biological catalysis.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/07_Turner_.title: 07_Turner_2009_NatChemBiol
backbone/core_reviews/summary/07_Turner_.content:
Directed evolution drives the next generation of biocatalysts (Turner, Nat. Chem. Biol. 2009)
Citation & scope
Review focused on directed evolution as the core engine for modern biocatalyst creation: library design (from huge random to small, high-quality libraries), screening/selection methods, exploiting promiscuity/neutral drift, case studies (notably MAO-N), and steps toward new-to-nature functions and artificial metalloenzymes.
Thesis / what’s new
Industrial-grade biocatalysts require activity, selectivity, and process stability; the field has shifted from brute-force 10⁸–10¹⁰ libraries to targeted strategies (CAST/ISM, reduced alphabets, statistical models like ProSAR) plus robust high-throughput screens, delivering big gains with 10³–10⁶ variants.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Discovery→Optimization pipeline — identify a starting enzyme (screen collections, clone, or bioinformatics), then iteratively mutate–express–screen to improve activity/selectivity/stability; formulation/immobilization follows for process readiness.


Library strategy — move from random to semirational: active-site saturation and CAST/ISM on 2–3 residue groups; reduced amino-acid alphabets to shrink search; ProSAR statistically merges beneficial mutations, e.g., atorvastatin dehalogenase process gain ~4,000-fold with 38 mutations.


Screening & selection — chip assays, FACS with in-vitro compartmentalization, phage/yeast display, ribosome/mRNA display, colorimetric/indicator assays; also circular permutation to rewire scaffolds pre-evolution.


Promiscuity & neutral drift — leverage latent side activities and neutral drift to seed new functions; examples: halohydrin dehalogenase epoxide openings (→ oxazolidinone), arylmalonate decarboxylase → racemase (single mutation), alanine racemase → aldolase (5-orders rate gain), esterase → epoxide hydrolase.


Case study (MAO-N for deracemization of amines) — HRP/peroxide solid-phase color screen (~10⁵ variants/round) evolved MAO-N D5 (5 mutations) with broad scope and high (S)-selectivity; used for deracemizations (e.g., crispine A); later 1.8 Å structure rationalized channel mutations (A/B tunnels) affecting access/egress—not direct active-site contacts.


Expanded portfolios — evolved DERA for statin side-chain assembly (two C–C bonds), aldolases with flipped stereochemistry, transketolase selectivity swaps, P450 BM3 epoxygenase screens, epoxide hydrolase ee boosts, HNLs to optically pure cyanohydrins, in-vivo evolution of alkane hydroxylases, galactose oxidase retargeted to secondary alcohols.


Artificial metalloenzymes — embed Rh/V catalysts in protein scaffolds (e.g., biotin–streptavidin, carbonic anhydrase) for asymmetric hydrogenation, sulfoxidation, allylic alkylation; evolvable second-sphere control (chemogenetic optimization).


Toward de-novo/new function — computational Kemp/retro-aldol designs as weak starters that evolution can strengthen; pathway-level evolution emerging (carotenoids, assembly-line enzymes).


Key exemplars & metrics


ProSAR-driven enzyme in Lipitor route: ~4,000× volumetric productivity; 38 mutations accumulated.


MAO-N: wild-type kcat ~500 min⁻¹; evolved D5 handles 1°, 2°, 3° amines; desktop “template” predicted substrates (e.g., crispine A).


Screen throughput: MAO-N membrane assay ~10⁵ clones/round; FACS/double-emulsion enables very large library sorting.


Evolved catalysts across classes: aldolases (stereo-switch), transketolase (R/S swapping residues), P450 BM3 (styrene epoxidation assay), HNLs (cyanohydrins).


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
General C–H → C–OH screening remains hard; need better sequence–function algorithms to navigate rugged landscapes; de-novo design is still challenging; “you get what you screen for” caution—screen design can bias outcomes.
Outlook
Expect continued convergence of rational, semirational, and random approaches; more pathway-level evolution; exploitation of promiscuity as entry points; artificial metalloenzymes broaden reaction space. Directed evolution remains the workhorse to deliver robust, selective, process-ready biocatalysts.
Tags
Directed evolution; CAST/ISM; reduced alphabet; ProSAR; screening technologies (FACS, displays, chip); promiscuity & neutral drift; MAO-N deracemization; evolved DERA/aldolases/TK; P450 BM3; HNL; artificial metalloenzymes; de-novo design.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/08_Schmid_.title: 08_Schmid_2001_Nature
backbone/core_reviews/summary/08_Schmid_.content:
Industrial biocatalysis today and tomorrow (Schmid, Dordick, Hauer, Kiener, Wubbolts, Witholt, Nature 2001)
Citation & scope
Industry-focused snapshot of what was already working at scale (BASF, DSM, Lonza) and a pragmatic framework—“the biocatalysis cycle” (from biocatalyst selection → process & DSP → economics)—for taking a reaction to plant. Covers isolated enzymes vs whole cells, non-aqueous & multiphase media, gas-phase biocatalysis, in-situ product recovery, and cofactor recycling (in vivo & in vitro).
Thesis / what’s new
Industrial adoption hinges less on “can enzymes do it?” and more on availability of the right biocatalyst, hardware/DS choices kept simple, and economics; with directed evolution + medium/immobilization engineering, biocatalysis competes across fine chems, APIs, and some bulk.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


The biocatalysis cycle — iterate across enzyme/cell choice, stability, cofactor regeneration, multiphase media, immobilization, in-situ recovery, and costing.


Media engineering — organic solvents (incl. neat & scCO₂), two-liquid-phase systems for apolar/toxic substrates, and gas-phase biocatalysis; manage toxicity & mass transfer.


Formats — isolated enzymes for hydrolysis/isomerization; whole cells where cofactors are needed (cheaper recycling, multistep). Immobilization standard for reuse.


Cofactor strategies — in vivo (cells) and in vitro (FDH/GDH; CLEC-based LDH; electrochemical & mediator systems; new ATP regeneration with polyphosphate).


Downstream & ISR — precipitation, crystallization, liquid/solid extraction; phase-split from organic carriers in 2-phase systems; align DS with reactor choice early.


Industrial case blocks — BASF (lipase resolutions of alcohols/amines; nitrilase → R-mandelic acid), DSM (amidases → non-proteinogenic L-AAs; aspartame; 6-APA/7-ADCA routes), Lonza (N-heterocycles: ring hydroxylations, nitrilase + hydroxylase sequences; nicotine valorization).


Key exemplars & metrics


Whole-cell two-phase oxidations: typical activities 100–500 IU·L⁻¹, sustained 10–20 h, implying 5–25 t·m⁻³·yr⁻¹ STY for small molecules.
