Cost model (n-alkane → alcohol, 10 000 t·yr⁻¹): ~US8/kg** product; major costs: media (carbon/salts) ~**40%**, equipment **18–22%**, energy **10%**; feasibility rule-of-thumb: **>100 IU·L⁻¹** volumetric activity; target products **>20–30/kg (improvements might reach $5–10/kg).


BASF lipase platforms: chiral alcohols & amines (vinyl/activated donors) at hundreds-ton scale; nitrilase to R-mandelic acid at multiton.


DSM: amidases resolve Strecker amide libraries to L-AAs; thermolysin couples Z-Asp + D/L-Phe-OMe → aspartame; penicillin acylase for 6-APA and side-chain couplings.


Lonza: 6-hydroxynicotinic acid 65 g·L⁻¹, ~90% yield; 5-hydroxypyrazinecarboxylic acid 40 g·L⁻¹; (S)-nicotine → value-added pyridines (up to 30 g·L⁻¹).


In-vitro cofactor: Degussa L-tert-leucine with FDH/NADH recycling; HLADH-CLEC packed bed: NADH TTN ≈ 12 000; electrochemical NAD(P)H regeneration demonstrated.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Volumetric O₂ input/heat removal constrain whole-cell oxygenations at scale; solvent toxicity & mass transfer need 2-phase engineering; biocatalyst availability is often the real gate; regulatory & waste handling still shape choices.
Outlook
Expect growth wherever selectivity + DS simplicity pay: lipases, nitrilases, amidases remain mainstays; multiphase/gas-phase and in-situ recovery broaden the window; ongoing evolution/engineering and cofactor tech widen the addressable product value range.
Tags
Biocatalysis cycle; isolated enzymes vs whole cells; two-phase & gas-phase; immobilization; cofactor (in vivo/in vitro/electrochemical); ISR/DS; cost models; BASF/DSM/Lonza case studies; lipase resolutions; nitrilase; amidase; aspartame; 6-APA/7-ADCA.

Biocatalysis Field Topics - From Schmid et al. Nature 2001
Document ID: Schmid_2001_Nature
Core Topics Extracted:
1. The Biocatalysis Development Cycle

Definition: Systematic approach to developing industrial biocatalytic processes from product identification to economic implementation
Components: Biocatalyst selection, process engineering, economic evaluation, and iterative optimization
Application: Framework for rational development of commercial bioprocesses

2. Economic Feasibility Analysis

Definition: Cost analysis methodology for determining commercial viability of biocatalytic processes
Benchmark: Products valued >$20-30/kg with >1000 tons/year production and >100 IU/L volumetric activity
Cost Distribution: Equipment (18-22%), substrates (20%), medium/glucose (40%), energy (10%), waste (5%), personnel (2%)

3. Two-Liquid Phase Biocatalysis

Definition: Biotransformation systems using aqueous phase for cells and organic phase for substrates/products
Advantages: Handles toxic/hydrophobic compounds, enables efficient product recovery, uses established downstream processing
Applications: Alkane oxidation, aromatic compound transformation, heterocycle modification

4. Enzyme Catalysis in Organic Solvents

Definition: Biocatalytic reactions performed in non-aqueous media to overcome water solubility limitations
Benefits: Higher substrate solubility, reversed hydrolytic reactions, modified enzyme specificity
Activation Methods: Salt activation (>20,000-fold enhancement), crown ethers, transition-state analogues

5. Salt-Activated Enzyme Systems

Definition: Dramatic enzyme activation achieved through lyophilization with kosmotropic salts
Mechanism: Salts stabilize folded enzyme forms during lyophilization and in organic solvents
Performance: >20,000-fold rate enhancements with subtilisin and other enzymes in organic media

6. Biocatalytic Plastics Technology

Definition: Incorporation of enzymes into polymeric materials during polymerization to create immobilized biocatalysts
Applications: Packed-bed reactors, biocatalytic coatings, antifouling surfaces, diagnostic materials
Advantages: Controlled particle sizes, tailored material properties, enhanced stability

7. In Situ Product Recovery (ISPR)

Definition: Simultaneous product separation during biotransformation to overcome inhibition and improve yields
Methods: Crystallization, distillation, liquid extraction, adsorption onto solid phases
Benefits: Overcomes substrate/product inhibition, prevents product decay, enables higher concentrations

8. Industrial Lipase Applications

Definition: Commercial use of lipases for enantioselective transformations in pharmaceutical and chemical industries
Mechanisms: Transesterification with vinyl esters/anhydrides for kinetic resolution of alcohols and amines
Scale: BASF produces hundreds of tons annually of chiral alcohols and amines using lipase processes

9. Nitrilase-Based Industrial Processes

Definition: Commercial production of amino- and hydroxycarboxylic acids through stereoselective nitrile hydrolysis
Strategy: Integration with existing HCN chemistry to access new chiral intermediates
Example: BASF’s multiton-scale R-mandelic acid production from racemizing cyanohydrins

10. Non-Proteinogenic Amino Acid Production

Definition: Industrial synthesis of unnatural amino acids through enzymatic resolution of racemic amides
Technology: DSM’s amidase toolbox from P. putida, M. neoaurum, O. antropii with varied substrate ranges
Recycling: Both enantiomers accessible through racemization of undesired isomer

11. Semisynthetic Antibiotic Manufacturing

Definition: Green biocatalytic routes for producing β-lactam antibiotics replacing harsh chemical processes
Process: Penicillin acylase for 6-APA production, enzymatic coupling for semisynthetic derivatives
Advantages: Mild conditions preserving labile β-lactam rings, eliminating low-temperature chemistry

12. N-Heterocycle Functionalization

Definition: Lonza’s biocatalytic routes for selective modification of aromatic N-heterocycles
Applications: Selective hydroxylation, kinetic resolution, oxidation of methyl groups
Examples: 6-hydroxynicotinic acid (65 g/L), 5-hydroxypyrazinecarboxylic acid for antituberculosis drugs

13. Renewable Resource Utilization

Definition: Using natural materials like nicotine from tobacco for pharmaceutical precursor synthesis
Strategy: Selective functionalization of natural alkaloids to produce drug analogues
Products: Epibatidine analogues, functionalized pyridines from (S)-nicotine biotransformation

14. Whole-Cell Cofactor Regeneration

Definition: Using metabolically active cells for in vivo regeneration of expensive cofactors like NAD(P)H
Advantages: Eliminates need for external cofactor addition, enables complex multi-enzyme reactions
Applications: Oxidoreductions, phosphorylated compound synthesis, oligosaccharide production

15. Steroid Biotransformation Industry

Definition: Large-scale conversion of plant sterols to pharmaceutical precursors using microbial systems
Scale: >1000 tons/year worldwide market for androstenedione and androsta-dien-dione
Processes: Hydroxylations (11α/11β), dehydrogenations, reductions using fungal and bacterial strains

16. Electrochemical Cofactor Regeneration

Definition: In vitro NAD(P)H regeneration using electrical current and mediator compounds
Methods: Rhodium complexes, mediator proteins, artificial redox mediators
Applications: Enables isolated enzyme use for oxidoreduction reactions without expensive cofactor consumption

17. Gas-Phase Biocatalysis

Definition: Enzyme or cell catalysis with gaseous reactants, avoiding toxic solvents
Advantages: Simple downstream processing, efficient mass transfer, avoids solvent toxicity
Suitability: Compounds that can be volatilized at operating conditions

18. High-Density Cell Cultivation

Definition: Achieving 10-40 g/L dry cell mass in two-phase systems for industrial biotransformations
Performance: 100-500 IU/L volumetric activities, 10-20 hour stability, 5-25 tons/m³/year space-time yields
Host: E. coli preferred for recombinant systems despite limited solvent resistance

19. Combinatorial Biocatalysis

Definition: High-throughput generation of compound libraries using enzymatic transformations
Applications: Drug discovery, agrochemicals, biopolymers, nutraceuticals, separation media
Advantages: Enzyme selectivity enables diverse natural product and synthetic derivatives

20. Future Biocatalytic Technologies

Definition: Emerging technologies combining miniaturization, automation, and advanced enzyme engineering
Innovations: Biochips, microfluidic systems, protein-based nanomaterials, directed evolution integration
Potential: Proteomics applications, functional genomics, automated library screening


Review Character: Comprehensive industrial perspective covering current commercial processes and future technological directions from leading European chemical companies.
Unique Contributions: Real-world economic analysis, detailed industrial case studies, concrete production scales and costs, technology transfer insights from academic research to industrial implementation.
Key Insights: Demonstrates that biocatalysis has moved beyond proof-of-concept to large-scale commercial reality, with clear economic drivers and technological enablers for continued growth.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/09_Bommari.title: 09_Bommarius_2015_AnnuRevChemBiomolEng
backbone/core_reviews/summary/09_Bommari.content:
Biocatalysis: A Status Report (Bommarius, Annu. Rev. Chem. Biomol. Eng. 2015)
Citation & scope
Field overview focused on three historic bottlenecks—designability, stability, and limited off-the-shelf enzyme panels—and on practical progress in protein engineering, quantitative stability/TTN modeling, and discovery/creation of new biocatalysts.
Thesis / what’s new
Positions a “third wave” of data-driven/semirational engineering (restricted libraries, CASTing, ISM) plus quantitative process stability models (TTN/kd,obs) as the enablers turning bespoke enzymes into a broader, reliable toolbox; showcases both novel native functions and engineered/de-novo reactivities entering synthesis.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Strengths vs weaknesses — stellar selectivity and mild conditions vs (i) slow/serendipitous design, (ii) limited operational stability, (iii) too few ready enzymes.


Protein-engineering playbook — restricted libraries, CASTing, ISM to shrink libraries yet raise hit rates; SCHEMA; consensus design; B-FIT (stabilize mobile residues); FRESCO (computational library → screen).


Stability as a process metric — rigorous TTN = kcat,obs/kd,obs under Lumry–Eyring deactivation; distinguish thermodynamic Tm from kinetic (process) stability; report STY, and for synthesis favor v_avg and K_M,eff over just kcat or kcat/KM.


Multi-stress robustness — correlations across heat/solvent/salt/interface stresses; examples where thermostabilization co-improves solvent tolerance.


Novel native functions — inverting alkylsulfatases (no chemical analogue), alkene “ozonidase” oxidations, BBE-mediated oxidative Pictet–Spengler chemistry.


Engineered & de-novo reactivity — MAO-N evolution for deracemizations; AmDHs from AADHs (two-mutation switch); P450→P411 platforms for carbene/nitrene transfer (cyclopropanation, C–H amination, N–H insertion); computational Kemp eliminases.


Applications — pharma case studies (e.g., atorvastatin side-chain via ADH/KRED/HHDH routes) underline process-level metrics and cofactor/DSP tactics.


Key exemplars & metrics


Engineering tools: CASTing/ISM schematics; restricted codons cut screens by orders of magnitude at ≥95% coverage.


Stability leaps: xylanase Tm 61→96 °C; consensus-engineered GDH 10⁶× half-life increase; LEH via FRESCO +35 °C Tm, ~250× kd improvement.


Cross-stress wins: thermostable lipase A variants also more solvent-tolerant; thermophilic TOYE resists heat/solvent/denaturants better than mesophilic OYEs.


Operational modeling: TTN formula; v_avg ≈ vmax/(1 + K_M,eff/[S]0) at 99% conversion; define Ef to compare variants at high [S].


New native reactions: alkylsulfatases (E up to >200 with medium tuning); alkene oxidase cleaving styrenes to carbonyls with high chemoselectivity; BBE deracemization/cyclizations in biphasic media, >97% ee.


Engineered functions: MAO-N lineage (D-series) expands from primary → tertiary amines; AmDH from LeuDH/PheDH (2-site switch + CASTing); P411 variants: cyclopropanation (up to 97% ee), C–H amination (TTN ~383, 73% ee).


Pharma: L. brevis ADH reduction for Lipitor side-chain (≥99.5% ee; optimized NADP⁺ TTN); alternative KRED/HHDH routes (Codexis).


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Sparse public STY/throughput data; overreliance on kcat/KM for synthesis conditions; enzyme catalogs still thin for many transformations; design still needs assays + structure; standardization across reporting remains needed.
Outlook
Marry semirational design with quantitative stability targets and assayable new functions; expect further convergence of stabilization + scope expansion (native and abiological) and more case-driven industrial adoption.
Tags
CASTing/ISM; restricted libraries; TTN/kd,obs; v_avg & K_M,eff; cross-stress stability; consensus/SCHEMA/B-FIT/FRESCO; sulfatases; alkene oxidase; BBE; MAO-N; AmDH; P411 carbene/nitrene; Kemp eliminase; atorvastatin route.
Biocatalysis Field Topics — From Bommarius 2015 (“Biocatalysis: A Status Report”)
Document ID: Bommarius_2015_AnnualRevChemBioEng
What this review sets out to do. It frames three core bottlenecks—limited designability, stability ceilings, and a shortage of ready-to-use enzymes—then surveys how new protein-engineering tools, quantitative stability models, and genuinely new-to-biology enzymes are closing those gaps.
Core topics extracted


Process-relevant performance metrics (not just kcat/KM). Introduces the efficiency function (Ef) and catalytic effectiveness (_v_avg at high conversion) as better predictors under industrial substrate loads.


Total Turnover Number (TTN) as lifetime output. Links TTN to unfolding/deactivation via Lumry–Eyring kinetics; gives simple relations between kcat, kd,obs and TTN.


Space–time yield thinking. Ties productivity to solubility constraints ([S]max, [P]max) and residence time—grounding bench metrics in reactor reality.


Restricted libraries for directed evolution. Shows why restricted saturation and coverage planning beat naïve random mutagenesis; quantifies transformants needed.


CASTing (Combinatorial Active-Site Saturation Testing). Targeted multi-site saturation guided by structure/mechanism; practical coverage (2–4 positions).


Iterative Saturation Mutagenesis (ISM). Multi-round CASTing to capture epistasis and synergy; pathway-independent properties for final variants.


Stability modeling that predicts output. Quantitative links between kinetic/thermodynamic stability and process lifetime; emphasizes kd,obs over Tm alone.


Cross-protection across stresses. Improvements to heat stability often bring solvent/interfacial robustness (examples: lipase A via B-FIT; thermophilic OYEs).


Computational stabilization pipelines (e.g., FRESCO). Practical flow from structure → in silico ΔΔG filters → MD screens → combine stabilizing mutations.


Consensus & recombination for stability. Consensus GDHs tolerate salts/solvents; SCHEMA-recombined cellulases validate additivity and single hot-spot fixes.


Medium & interface engineering. Stabilization against bubbles, shear, and cavitation (e.g., FDH Cys→Ser/Ala) and biphasic/solvent choices that boost selectivity.


MAO-N evolution for deracemization of (secondary/tertiary) amines. Stepwise pocket enlargement across D-series variants; crystal-structure rationale.


Amine dehydrogenases (AmDHs). Evolved ADHs → AmDHs enabling reductive amination as a single-enzyme transform (process-relevant chiral amines).


Cytochrome P450s with new reactivity. Engineered P450BM3 variants perform abiological carbene/nitrene transfer-like chemistry and control cis/trans + e.e. at scale-relevant yields.


Alkene “ozonidases.” Discovery of a Mn³⁺ enzyme from Trametes hirsuta that cleaves alkenes to carbonyls with O₂—mechanistically distinct from (mono)dioxygenases.


Bicovalent-flavin enzymes (BBE) for Pictet–Spengler chemistry. Solvent-compatible oxidative cyclizations/deracemizations broaden heterocycle synthesis options.


Enantiocomplementary sulfatases. Inverting/retaining sulfatases give anti-Kazlauskas access to (S)-alcohols; simple medium tweaks jump E from ~4 to >200.


De novo designed enzymes (Kemp eliminases). KE70/KE07/KE59 show computation → evolution pipelines; proficiency rises 10⁶–10⁸-fold with stability rescue.


Metric awareness for variant ranking. Warns that “vmax/KM-is-fine” thinking can mislead at high conversion due to product inhibition; advocates _v_avg.


Industrial anchoring. Connects metrics to case landscapes (statin side-chains, etc.) and emphasizes confidentiality barriers around productivity datasets.


Why this review is distinctive


Metrics that matter. It centers Ef, _v_avg (to 99% conversion), TTN and space–time yield—tools chem/bioprocess folks can actually use to triage variants and size reactors.


From “stability is Tm” to “stability is output.” Provides model-based, stress-aware stabilization strategies and shows cross-stress correlations (T₅₀ vs C₅₀).


New enzymes, not just better ones. Highlights genuinely novel reactivity (ozonidases, BBE) and computational de novo catalysts, expanding the synthetic playbook.


How it plugs into your backbone


Bridges Reetz’s evolutionary toolkit and Arnold’s “new chemistry” with process-valid performance metrics and stability engineering that translate to plant conditions.


Complements earlier industry reviews by giving concrete, quantitative screens/targets for variant selection (Ef/_v_avg/TTN) rather than only conversion/yield narratives.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/10_Yi_2021.title: 10_Yi_2021_ChemSocRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/10_Yi_2021.content:
Recent trends in biocatalysis (Yi, Bayer, Badenhorst, Wu, Doerr, Höhne, Bornscheuer, Chem. Soc. Rev. 2021)
Citation & scope
Panoramic review of where the field is headed: advanced technologies (ML/AI, automation, ultra-high-throughput screening), biosensors for screening and dynamic control, and novel enzymes/cascades enabling enzymatic total synthesis of complex molecules (natural products, drugs).
Thesis / what’s new
Biocatalysis is entering an era of technology integration + intelligent manufacturing: ML/AI + standardized metadata/ontologies + automation + UHTP screening are converging with synthetic biology to design product-oriented, multi-enzyme pathways—blurring the old line between “isolated-enzyme” biocatalysis and whole-cell biotransformations.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


ML/AI & data infrastructure — Need high-quality data + metadata and shared ontologies (OLS, Pistoia, Allotrope), plus open lab standards (SiLA, AnIML) and reporting (STRENDA) to make ML truly predictive. Tools highlighted: EnzymeMiner (soluble expressibility + activity hints) and Galaxy SynBioCAD (retrosynthesis→design→liquid-handling).


Structure/design leap — AlphaFold-class predictors and ML-derived force fields accelerate design; epistasis remains central in reaching new functions.


UHTP screening platforms — From microtiter automation to droplet microfluidics:
• FADS fluorescence droplet sorting up to ~30 kHz; picoliter volumes enable low-nM detection.
• AADS absorbance droplet sorting ~300 Hz (larger ~80 µm droplets; ~10 µM detection for strong chromophores).
• Double emulsions → sort on standard flow cytometers.
• MS-coupled droplets: analysis up to ~30 Hz, sorting ~6 Hz (destructive; delay-line logistics).
• Practical headaches: dye leakage between droplets, surfactant effects; Pickering emulsions (silica nanoparticles; e.g., Fluoro-Phase) mitigate but don’t eliminate.


Genetically encoded biosensors — TF- and riboswitch-based sensors enable (i) UHTP selection/evolution, (ii) in-vivo feedback control of flux, and (iii) real-time monitoring; design space includes promoter/RBS tuning, hybrid TF–riboswitch controllers, and CRISPR/dCas9 burden-responsive feedback or quorum-sensing CRISPRi for consortia.


Application arenas — Case blocks on flavonoids, steroids/terpenoids, and other natural products: heterologous routes use novel enzymes, pathway swaps, artificial cofactor cycles, and engineered key steps to close gaps to enzymatic total synthesis.


Key exemplars & metrics


FADS: kHz-rate sorting of picoliter droplets; AADS: ~300 Hz, ~10 µM limit for strong absorbers; MS-droplet pipelines: ~15 k droplets/6 h sorted at ~6 Hz.


Leakage problem quantified across dyes (seconds → days); Pickering emulsions (amphiphilic silica) markedly slow leakage; commercial mixes (e.g., Fluoro-Phase) available.


Biosensors: fluoride-responsive riboswitch drives fluorinase pathways; TF sensors fielded for steroids and flavonoids (naringenin/quercetin/kaempferol), with DoE workflows expanding range/sensitivity.


Tooling for discovery/design: EnzymeMiner, SynBioCAD; standards SiLA/AnIML/STRENDA emphasized as prerequisites for robust ML.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)


ML still bottlenecked by data quality, metadata, and ontology alignment; many current models use crude system assumptions and under-capture dynamics/epistasis.


Droplet technologies face leakage, detection-modality bias, and complex hardware; AADS/MS variants trade throughput for generality.


Whole-product enzymatic total syntheses remain hard where pathways are unknown or heterologous expression/cofactor context is problematic.


Outlook
Convergence of ML-guided design, automation, UHTP droplets, and smart biosensors will normalize designer cascades in cells or cell-free, making enzymatic total synthesis practical for many complex targets; the “biocatalysis vs biotransformation” boundary continues to dissolve—productivity (g L⁻¹ h⁻¹) will decide formats.
Tags
ML/AI; metadata/ontologies (OLS/Pistoia/Allotrope); SiLA/AnIML/STRENDA; EnzymeMiner; SynBioCAD; AlphaFold; epistasis; droplet microfluidics (FADS/AADS/MS); leakage/Pickering; TF & riboswitch biosensors; CRISPR/dCas9 feedback; flavonoids/steroids total synthesis.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/11_Hanefel.title: 11_Hanefeld_2022_ChemSocRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/11_Hanefel.content:
Biocatalysis making waves in organic chemistry (Hanefeld, Hollmann, Paul, Chem. Soc. Rev. 2022)
Citation & scope
State-of-the-field review arguing that the “third wave” (directed evolution + smarter engineering) has pushed biocatalysis to the center of organic synthesis. Focus on C–C bond construction, C–H functionalization (C–X), and multi-enzyme cascades, with historical framing of the three waves.
Thesis / what’s new
Hydrolases are mature; the action is in C–C bond-forming enzymes and selective oxidations/reductions. Enzyme engineering now routinely tunes scope and selectivity, enabling reactions once thought “non-enzymatic” (e.g., carbene/nitrene transfer via engineered P450s).
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Waves of biocatalysis — 1st: natural enzymes; 2nd: mutagenesis/screening; 3rd: directed evolution shrinking libraries & raising success.


C–C bond formation — HNL cyanations & Henry; ThDP umpolung couplings; aldolases (DERA, DHAP→FSA/DHA); Pictet–Spenglerases; methyltransferases; acyltransferases (ATase); heme-enzyme carbene C–C (P411).


C–H→C–X functionalization — Aromatic & aliphatic hydroxylations (FPMO, P450, peroxygenase), dioxygenase aromaticity-breaking cis-diols, halogenases (o/m/p control), nitration (TxtE), nitrene amination (P411).


Stability / loading & media — Stability challenges addressed by engineering/immobilisation (not covered here) and alternative solvents for hydrophobes. Case-by-case catalyst choice urged.


Cascades — Multi-enzyme sequences solve thermodynamics & cofactor balance; landmark 17-step corrin (vitamin B12) scaffold, and Merck islatravir cascade.


Key exemplars & metrics


FSA (DHA-dependent aldolase) variants: broad donors/acceptors (incl. cyclic ketones; aromatic aldehydes).


Engineered P450BM3 + arbutin synthase: benzene → arbutin, 60% isolated yield (selective para-dihydroxylation).


Fatty-acid hydroxylation: α, β, ω, ω-1 position control across P450s (prospect of position-programmable panels).


Halogenases/haloperoxidases: enzyme-overridden o/m/p regiocontrol on aromatics demonstrated.


Carbene/nitrene transfer: P411s unlock abiological C–C and C–H amination manifolds.


Mega-cascades: corrin pathway—12 enzymes/17 steps, ~20% overall yield to hydrogenobyrinic acid.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Monooxygenases can be too specific (biosynthetic) or too promiscuous (detox enzymes); engineering fixes this. Balancing thermodynamics and compatibility in multi-step settings remains design-critical.
Outlook
Expect more engineered reactivity classes, deeper cascade design, and continued integration with process (media, immobilisation, flow) as biocatalysis fills gaps alongside classical methods.
Tags
Waves/history; C–C (HNL, ThDP, aldolases, NCS, MTases, ATase, P411); C–H→C–X (P450/FPMO/peroxygenase/dioxygenase/halogenase/nitration); stability & media; cascades (B12, islatravir).

backbone/core_reviews/summary/12_Carrea_.title: 12_Carrea_2000_ACIE
backbone/core_reviews/summary/12_Carrea_.content:
Properties and Synthetic Applications of Enzymes in Organic Solvents (Carrea & Riva, Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2000)
Citation & scope
Classic review of nonaqueous enzymology: how enzymes behave in nearly anhydrous or low-water organic media and how to exploit that for synthetic (non-hydrolytic) chemistry—with practical guidance on water activity (a_w) control, “pH memory,” medium engineering, immobilization, and reaction classes (esterifications, transesterifications, amidations/peptide formation, acylations of sugars, kinetic resolutions, dynamic kinetic resolutions).
Thesis / what’s new
Enzymes can function effectively in organic solvents if you deliberately control their microenvironment. Two levers dominate: thermodynamic water activity (a_w) and the enzyme’s ionization state (“pH memory” from the last aqueous buffer). With the right solvent and a_w, hydrolases switch cleanly to synthetic direction (ester/amide formation), often with higher chemo- and enantioselectivity and simpler downstream processing than in water.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Why organic media? — Drives equilibria toward condensation (little water), increases substrate solubility for hydrophobes, suppresses side hydrolysis, and can improve selectivity; trade-off is lower intrinsic turnover and the need to manage enzyme integrity.


Enzyme preparation — Lyophilize from defined buffers (to set “pH memory”); add lyoprotectants/salts; use immobilized formats to enhance stability, reuse, and handling in nonpolar media.


Water activity control (a_w) — The critical state variable in nonaqueous biocatalysis. Set/hold a_w using salt-hydrate pairs, controlled humid gases, sieves, or pre-equilibration; a_w tunes rate, selectivity, and equilibrium.


“pH memory” / ionization — Apparent pH in organic media equals the ionization state it had before drying; pick the pre-drying buffer/ionic form to maximize activity and selectivity in the target solvent.


Medium engineering — Choose solvents with appropriate polarity/H-bond capacity (often hydrophobic, non–H-bonding solvents are best for hydrolases); tiny water additions (“micro-aqueous”) may raise rates but risk back-hydrolysis and pH drift.


Kinetics/thermodynamics in nonaqueous — Rates typically drop (transition-state destabilization, decreased flexibility), yet kinetic stability increases (slower unfolding); operate at high substrate concentrations to offset higher apparent K_M and maintain productivity.


Reaction classes & strategies —
• Esterifications/transesterifications by lipases (use activated acyl donors like vinyl/alkenyl esters to pull equilibrium).
• Amidations/peptide synthesis by proteases under low a_w.
• Acylation of polyols/sugars (medium and acyl-donor choice dictates regioselectivity).
• Kinetic resolutions (often higher E in nonaqueous); dynamic kinetic resolution with in situ racemization.


Formats & supports — Free powders vs immobilized enzymes (e.g., acrylic resins, mesoporous silica, CLECs/CLEAs) for superior operational stability and integration in packed beds/flow; pre-equilibration of the formulation with the intended a_w is emphasized.


Process design — High substrate loads, minimal water, simple phase behavior (neat or biphasic), and in-situ water removal (molecular sieves) are recurrent themes for scale-up.


Key exemplars & “rules of thumb” (for your tables)


Hydrolases as synthases: lipase-catalyzed acylations/aminolyses in nonpolar solvents; vinyl/isopropenyl esters drive conversions to completion by removing coproduct (acetaldehyde/acetone).


Protease-mediated peptide formation in nearly anhydrous media under controlled a_w (suppresses hydrolysis, favors coupling).


Kinetic resolution of secondary alcohols/amines: E-values frequently improve relative to aqueous systems when a_w and solvent H-bonding are optimized.


a_w setting via salt-hydrate pairs and pre-equilibration of enzyme/solvent/substrate—central for reproducibility and for mapping rate vs selectivity vs equilibrium.


Medium selection: hydrophobic, weakly interacting solvents favored; strongly H-bonding polar solvents (e.g., DMSO/DMF) risk inactivation. (Consistent with later surveys of nonaqueous/IL media.)


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Unclear general predictors for solvent compatibility; assay comparability poor without specifying a_w; rate penalties vs water are common; micro-aqueous boosts can re-introduce hydrolysis and pH drift; careful pretreatment (buffer, lyoprotectants) + a_w control is mandatory for robustness.
Outlook (authors)
Routine synthesis in organic media will rely on precise a_w control, buffer/ionization programming, and immobilized/engineered formats to balance activity, selectivity, and longevity—laying foundations later expanded by ionic liquids and flow implementations.
Tags
Nonaqueous enzymology; water activity (a_w); “pH memory”; solvent selection; micro-aqueous vs anhydrous; lipase transesterification; protease amidation/peptides; sugar acylation; kinetic/dynamic kinetic resolution; immobilization; molecular sieves; high-substrate loading.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/13_Sheldon.title: 13_Sheldon_2007_ChemRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/13_Sheldon.content:
Biocatalysis in Ionic Liquids (van Rantwijk & Sheldon, Chem. Rev. 2007)
Citation & scope
Foundational review of enzyme and whole-cell catalysis in ionic liquids (ILs): solvent properties, enzyme compatibility (aqueous vs nearly anhydrous ILs), reaction classes (lipases/esterases, proteases, glycosidases, redox enzymes, HNLs), and process/DS options (recycling, evaporation, biphasic scCO₂, IL membranes).
Thesis / what’s new
ILs offer non-volatile, tunable media that often match/exceed classic organic solvents for activity, stability, and (enantio)selectivity; no single “best IL” exists—medium must be tuned to enzyme + substrate. Emerging process tricks (e.g., scCO₂/IL biphasic, product evaporation, IL membranes) hint at greener, recyclable biocatalysis.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


IL fundamentals & enzyme compatibility — purity, water activity, (ill-defined) polarity; compatibility not predictable from simple scales; impurities (e.g., halide/HF) can deactivate enzymes.


Aqueous IL mixtures — many enzymes tolerate 30–70% IL; effects aren’t cleanly explained by Hofmeister series; pH shifts and a_w matter.


Nearly anhydrous ILs — hydrolases (lipases esp.) work well; activity/solubility is anion-dependent; dissolution can mean denaturation unless using special ILs that preserve activity.


Reaction classes — Lipases/esterases (resolutions, perhydrolysis, aminolysis), proteases (peptide/amide chemistry, resolutions), glycosidases (carbohydrate derivatization), redox enzymes, HNL lyases.


Whole cells in IL systems — certain hydrophobic ILs preserve membrane integrity better than typical organic solvents.


Process intensification — catalyst recycling by phase-split with ethers; product/water evaporation (ILs have near-zero vapor pressure); IL–scCO₂ biphasic for continuous extraction; IL membranes for facilitated transport/resolution.


Key exemplars & metrics


scCO₂/IL biphasic lipase: Novozym 435 retained in IL, substrates/products in scCO₂; rate ~8× higher than pure scCO₂, high operational stability; with in-situ racemization gave ~80% yield and >97% ee (IL-dependent).


Kinetic resolutions in ILs: For arylalkanols (e.g., 21, 23, 26–28), E often improved vs TBME/toluene; for methyl mandelate (24) E 10→>250 depending on immobilization carrier + IL.


Medium sensitivity/impurities: Opposite outcomes for 1-phenylethanol resolution across labs traced to IL impurities (e.g., halide/HF); esterases far less tolerant than lipases.


Non-natural lipase chemistry: Aminolysis to octanamide in [BMIm][BF₄] at 40–70% of tert-BuOH rate; perhydrolysis epoxidation in IL slightly slower than ACN.


Carbohydrate & flavonoid acylations: IL choice flips rate/selectivity; selective acylation of naringin and rutin showed enzyme/IL-dependent activity order changes.


Downstream tricks: Swap vinyl → methyl esters and evaporate methanol to drive transesterifications to completion without acetaldehyde inhibition; easy ether extraction leaves enzyme in IL for reuse.


IL membranes: Supported IL membranes enabled ibuprofen resolutions; [BMIm][NTf₂] gave higher permeate fluxes than dodecane.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)


Predictability gap: no robust theory to predict enzyme–IL compatibility; polarity/logP/Hofmeister often fail.


Purity & toxicity: chloride/HF impurities deactivate enzymes; classic imidazolium ILs raise eco-toxicity/biodegradability concerns—need greener ILs.


Enzyme class limits: many esterases/proteases require some water; penicillin G acylase needs high a_w (~0.8) even in ILs.


Outlook (authors)
Expect cheaper, biocompatible ILs; wider adoption where ILs enable highly polar substrates or innovative DS (evaporation, scCO₂ extraction, membranes). Biggest “green” wins likely from process design (IL+scCO₂, recycling, multicatalyst cascades), not just solvent swaps.
Tags
Ionic liquids; enzyme compatibility & water activity; lipases/esterases; proteases; glycosidases; redox; HNL; kinetic resolution; perhydrolysis/aminolysis; scCO₂–IL biphasic; product evaporation; catalyst recycling; IL membranes; impurities & toxicity; green IL development.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/14_Mateo_2.title: 14_Mateo_2007_BiotechnolAdv
backbone/core_reviews/summary/14_Mateo_2.content:
Improvement of enzyme activity, stability and selectivity via immobilization techniques (Mateo, Palomo, Fernández-Lorente, Guisán, Fernández-Lafuente, Enzyme Microb. Technol. 2007)
Citation & scope
Seminal review on how immobilization itself (choice of support + chemistry + conditions) can engineer enzymes to improve stability, activity, selectivity, and product inhibition—with practical recipes (glyoxyl/epoxy supports, glutaraldehyde crosslinking, polymer coatings, CLEAs) and many case studies.
Thesis / what’s new
Tailor-made immobilization can (i) operationally stabilize enzymes on porous solids, (ii) rigidify structures via multipoint covalent attachment (especially on glyoxyl-agarose), (iii) stabilize multimeric enzymes by multisubunit binding + post-crosslinking, (iv) hyperactivate lipases by fixing the “open-lid” form, (v) tune enantioselectivity by orientation/microenvironment, and (vi) mitigate inhibition using polymer nano-environments—often matching or surpassing protein engineering outcomes.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Operational stabilization on porous supports — protects from gas–liquid interfaces, aggregation, and proteases; note non-porous nanoparticles lose these benefits unless coated.


Multipoint covalent immobilization — glyoxyl-agarose and epoxy supports; stabilize via many enzyme–support linkages; careful control of pH (alkaline), time, temperature, buffer to maximize linkage without activity loss.


Stabilizing multimeric enzymes — multisubunit anchoring + post-immobilization crosslinking for oligomers; CLECs/CLEAs also lock quaternary structure.


Hyperactivation of lipases — fix the open-lid state via hydrophobic adsorption (interfacial activation) or detergent-induced forms captured as CLEAs or by on-support glutaraldehyde crosslinking.


Modulating selectivity — immobilization orientation/rigidity can invert enantio-preference and raise E from ~1 to >100; emphasize building libraries of derivatives (different supports/conditions) to discover optimal behavior.


Reducing inhibition — build hydrophilic polymer shells, co-aggregate with polyelectrolytes, or entrap in Lentikats® to alter partitioning and raise apparent Ki; mild active-site/allosteric distortions may selectively weaken inhibitor binding.


Combining with protein/chemical engineering — surface amination, directed evolution for post-immobilization activity retention, microtiter-scale immobilization for rapid screening.


Key exemplars & metrics (for your tables)


Multipoint glyoxyl-agarose often gives 10³–10⁴-fold stabilization with >60% activity recovery across diverse enzymes; epoxy supports similar but usually lower.


Multimeric enzymes (e.g., FDHs, DAOs, catalase, β-galactosidase): multisubunit immobilization + crosslinking prevents dissociation and boosts operational stability.


Lipase hyperactivation: hydrophobic adsorption can increase rates up to ~20× for small hydrophobic substrates; detergent-fixed lipase-CLEAs keep hyperactivity in aqueous media.


Inhibition relief: immobilized lactases exhibit much weaker product inhibition, enabling full hydrolysis of 5% lactose where soluble enzymes stall well below completion.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)


No one-size-fits-all: random protocols can lower activity; must match support chemistry + orientation + rigidity to enzyme and process.


Data comparability: activities/stabilities are assay-dependent; mass-transfer artifacts common.


Orientation control is still crude; getting single, defined orientations would unlock bigger, more predictable selectivity/activity shifts.


Outlook (authors)
Future biocatalyst design will blend combinatorial immobilization libraries (supports/chemistries/conditions) with directed evolution and surface engineering to deliberately control orientation, rigidity, microenvironment, and multimer stability—making immobilization a first-class engineering knob, not just a work-up step.
Tags
Porous-support operational stabilization; Multipoint covalent (glyoxyl/epoxy); Glutaraldehyde crosslinking; Multisubunit stabilization; CLECs/CLEAs; Lipase open-lid fixation; Hydrophobic adsorption; Detergent-assisted hyperactivation; Selectivity tuning / E-factor up to >100; Polymer nano-environment; Lentikats; Product-inhibition mitigation; Orientation control; Directed evolution + immobilization synergy.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/15_Sheldon.title: 15_Sheldon_2013_ChemSocRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/15_Sheldon.content:
Enzyme immobilisation in biocatalysis: why, what and how (Sheldon & van Pelt, Chem. Soc. Rev. 2013)
Citation & scope
Tutorial review covering rationale, terminology, methods, supports, and performance factors for enzyme immobilisation; emphasizes cost, stability, reuse, reactor fit, and emerging supports/formats (mesoporous silicas, hydrogels, smart polymers, CLECs/CLEAs, magnetic systems, microchannels).
Thesis / what’s new
Industrial biocatalysis often hinges on immobilisation to gain operational stability, recyclability, and clean product, but method choice is context-specific. The review systematizes three method families (support-binding, entrapment, carrier-free cross-linking) and standardizes metrics (immobilisation yield, efficiency, activity recovery), highlighting carrier-free approaches (CLEAs) as high-productivity, low-cost options.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Why immobilise — stability (heat/solvent/proteolysis), reuse, easy separation, lower product contamination/allergenicity, continuous operation.


Core methods — (i) Support binding (physical/ionic/covalent), (ii) Entrapment (sol–gels, hydrogels/cryogels), (iii) Carrier-free cross-linking (CLECs/CLEAs). Trade-offs: leaching vs. irreversibility, mass transfer, cost.


Terminology & metrics — Immobilisation yield, immobilisation efficiency, activity recovery; importance of assay conditions and mass transfer when interpreting numbers. Active-site titration distinguishes deactivation vs. inaccessibility.


Support classes — Synthetic polymers (e.g., acrylics; Eupergit/epoxy; silicone coatings), natural polymers (agarose/chitosan/DEAE-Sephadex), inorganics (silica, mesoporous SBA-15/MCM-41). Match pore/chemistry to enzyme & substrate.


Smart formats — Thermoresponsive polymers (polyNIPAM conjugates), magnetic nanoparticles (magnetic decantation, magnetically stabilised beds), protein-coated microcrystals (PCMCs) for organic media.


Carrier-free strategies — CLECs (crystallisation + cross-linking; robust but costly) and CLEAs (precipitation + cross-linking; cheap, high activity density, tunable composites incl. silica-CLEAs and magnetic CLEAs).


Process integration — Particle size vs. filterability/pressure-drop; packed beds, fluidised/magnetically stabilised beds, and enzyme-immobilised microchannel reactors for intensification.


Cascades — Combi-CLEAs to couple steps and drive equilibria (e.g., HNL + nitrilase).


Key exemplars & metrics


Penicillin amidase on Eupergit C: retained ~60% activity over >800 cycles (fixed-bed).


a-Chymotrypsin on modified mesoporous glass: ~1000× longer half-life vs free enzyme.


Novozym 435 silicone-coated: 92% activity retention, high anti-leaching/mechanical strength.


Tanabe process: aminoacylase on DEAE-Sephadex (ionic adsorption) for L-amino acid resolution (historic industrial benchmark).


PCMCs (subtilisin): 10³-fold activity boost in transesterification vs lyophilised powder in organics.


polyNIPAM–penicillin G amidase: near-free-enzyme activity; applied to cephalexin synthesis; temperature-triggered recovery.


CLEAs:


Penicillin G amidase-CLEA for ampicillin synthesis in organic media.


Alcalase-CLEA for peptide amidations and C-terminal ester interconversion; used for clopidogrel intermediate (S-2-Cl-PhGly) hydrolysis to 98% ee.


HNL-CLEAs: high ee in organic solvents; combi-CLEA (HNL+nitrilase) converts benzaldehyde → (S)-mandelic acid efficiently.


NHase-CLEAs: stabilise multimeric enzymes for nitrile hydration.




Microchannel reactors: CLEA membranes (e.g., a-chymotrypsin in PTFE tubing); thermophilic L-aminoacylase-CLEA packed in capillaries, ≥2 months activity retention at 4 °C.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)


No one-size-fits-all: enzyme surface chemistry (e.g., Lys density) dictates cross-linking success; may need proteic feeders (BSA), PEI, or poly-L-lysine for CLEAs.


Mass transfer vs particle size/porosity remains central; leaching for adsorption/entrapment in aqueous media; covalent binding sacrifices support reuse if enzyme dies.


Data comparability: activity numbers depend strongly on assay substrate/conditions; require application-like assays.


Outlook
Expect continued industrial push toward carrier-free (CLEA) and composite (silica/magnetic) systems, smarter stimuli-responsive carriers, and reactor-level intensification (packed/microfluidic, magnetically stabilised beds). Immobilisation choice should be driven by economics (enzyme cost per kg product) and process fit rather than a generic method preference.
Tags
Immobilisation rationale; metrics (yield/efficiency/activity recovery); support binding (adsorption/ionic/covalent); entrapment (sol–gel, hydrogels, Lentikats); CLECs; CLEAs/combi-CLEAs; smart polymers (polyNIPAM); magnetic nanoparticles; mesoporous silica; silicone coating; DEAE-Sephadex; microchannel reactors; packed/fluidised beds; peptide synthesis; β-lactams; HNL/nitrilase cascades.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/16_Britton.title: 16_Britton_2018_ChemSocRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/16_Britton.content:
Continuous flow biocatalysis (Britton, Majumdar, Weiss, Chem. Soc. Rev. 2018)
Citation & scope
Comprehensive review of equipment, immobilization modes, reactor designs, and applications for enzymes/whole cells in continuous flow; includes PAT, in-line separations, and multi-step chemoenzymatic sequences.
Thesis / what’s new
Pairing enzymes with flow hardware (pumps + BPRs + packed beds/microreactors/tube-in-tube) delivers higher STY, tighter control, easier reuse, and in-line workup; lipases dominate but scope spans oxidations, reductions, transaminations, phosphorylations, polymerizations, and cascades.
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Flow hardware & basics — pumps (semi-continuous vs continuous), back-pressure regulators to open high-T windows, reactor types: coils, chips, packed beds, cartridges, tube-in-tube for gases.


Biocatalyst formats — whole cell vs purified enzyme: trade-offs in cofactor supply, mass transfer, specificity, stability.


Immobilization strategies — adsorption, covalent (epoxides, GA, silica/chitosan), affinity (His-tag/Ni-NTA), entrapment (alginate, mesoporous silica, nanowires). Design asks: area, hydrophilicity, rigidity, regeneration, cost.


Unit operations in flow — in-line analytics (UV), catch-and-release cartridges, in-line separators (Zaiput), biphasic and IL media, recycle loops.


Cofactor management — GDH/FDH/G6PDH recycling, IPA “borrowing” for KREDs, co-immobilized enzyme+NADP(H) for self-sufficiency.


Applications — whole-cell reductions/resolutions, lipases (esterification, epoxidation via in situ peracids, polymerizations), HNL cyanohydrins, transaminations, phosphorylations, P450/oxygenases with gas transfer, wastewater lipid hydrolysis.


Cascades & spatial control — multi-step chemo-bio sequences, magnetic-bead microreactors, thin-film IMAC for rapid purify-&-immobilize and patterned zones.


Key exemplars & metrics


Whole-cell nitrile hydratase, dual packed beds at 4 °C: STY 93.2 g·L⁻¹·h⁻¹, stable 240 h (but at 30 °C lost >60% in 40 h).


Trehalosyl-maltodextrin (immobilized E. coli): 106.5 mg·mL⁻¹·h⁻¹ at 30% substrate; immobilization efficiency vs activity trade-off quantified.


scCO₂ whole-cell reduction of cyclohexanone: ~2× batch rate (0.24 vs 0.13 mmol·min⁻¹).


Lactose hydrolysis (immobilized K. lactis): ~40% at 125 min τ; CSTR ~quantitative at 600 min; cells stable 7 weeks at 4 °C.


(2R,5R)-hexanediol from 2,5-hexanedione (L. kefiri): 64 g·L⁻¹·d⁻¹, >99% ee, 19× better than batch; 6-day run kept 68% activity.


(S)-1-phenylethanol (R. glutinis): 75% yield; 30-day operation.


Biodiesel (immob. A. niger): 90% FAME at 250 mL·min⁻¹; higher flow improved mixing/yield.


Flurbiprofen resolution (dry mycelium): 2.64 mL·min⁻¹·g⁻¹, 90% ee, τ = 6.5 min (Vapourtec).


KRED/Novozym 435: alkyl esters ~97–100% conv (1 mL·min⁻¹); epoxidations 97–99% with BPR 100 psig (70 °C).


Ring-opening polymerization in microchannels: faster, higher Mw, <1% leaching.


Two-enzyme + chemical cyanohydrin sequence (Ley): HCN from cyanoformate 97% in 17.5 min (5 bar); HNL step 99% conv, 95% ee; acylation gives 75–99% yield.


Wastewater edible-oil hydrolysis (lipase on rice-husk carbon): up to 99% removal (τ = 4 h).


CAPE synthesis in IL with Novozym 435: 93% yield, τ = 2.5 h, stable 9 days.


Two-phase microfluidic KRED (PETN reductase) with in-line UV monitoring: higher yields than batch.


Acid phosphatase phosphorylation (covalent on PMA beads): 32 g, 78% isolated over 12 days; fed-batch comparable.


Transketolase multi-input reactor: 4.5× higher output concentration, 5× throughput (overcomes substrate inhibition).


Tube-in-tube O₂ hydroxylation: 17.7 g·L⁻¹·h⁻¹ STY.


o-Transaminase whole-cell packed bed: >99% ee amines; stable 5 days; silica catch-and-release workup.


Magnetic-bead microreactor cascade (ordered enzymes): >95% conv, >99:1 d.r. by spatial ordering.


Thin-film IMAC: 10-min purify+immobilize from lysate; 5-day run, 0.34% leaching; zone-wise kcat/KM balancing.


KRED + NADP(H) co-immobilized (IPA recycling): 80% yield; STY 104 g·L⁻¹·d⁻¹; 120 h stable.


Immobilized HEw-TA (Paradisi) with in-line separation: aldehydes → amines in 2 min vs 24 h batch; 50–99% isolated yields.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Mass-transfer barriers (whole cells, viscous feeds), enzyme leaching/denaturation, IL cost/greenness, accurate batch vs flow comparisons often lacking, need for standardized reporting (flow rate, reactor volume/ID, τ, BPR, T).
Outlook
Growth in packed-bed and microfluidic cascades, gas-liquid tube-in-tube oxygenations, cofactor self-sufficiency, and in-line purification; off-the-shelf systems (cartridges, separators, PAT) will democratize flow biocatalysis and speed API and functional materials manufacture.
Tags
Flow hardware; packed bed; tube-in-tube; immobilization (adsorption/covalent/affinity/entrapment); lipase repertoire; HNL cyanohydrins; KRED (IPA borrowing); transaminase; phosphorylation; oxygenases; cascades; PAT/UV; in-line separation; STY/τ/BPR; wastewater valorization.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/17_Schritt.title: 17_Schrittwieser_2018_ChemRev
backbone/core_reviews/summary/17_Schritt.content:
Paper 4 — Artificial Biocatalytic Linear Cascades for Preparation of Organic Molecules (Schrittwieser, Velikogne, Hall, Kroutil, Chem. Rev. 2018)
Citation & scope
A field-defining review that proposes a systematic classification for artificial biocatalytic cascades and surveys ~200+ examples across in vitro, in vivo, and chemoenzymatic settings, including flow systems.
Thesis / what’s new
Provides a unifying taxonomy for cascades (linear focus) by step count, catalyst count/type, redox logic (self-sufficient/neutral), operation mode (simultaneous vs sequential), cofactor regeneration (in vivo vs in vitro), and spatial organization (immobilization, scaffolds, membranes, flow). Uses this to map the landscape and highlight advantages and typical pitfalls (compatibility, thermodynamics, inhibition).
Higher-order topic map (authors’ framing)


Definitions & classification (Table 1): parameters include steps, catalysts, catalyst classes (enzyme/organocatalyst/metal), topology (linear/orthogonal/cyclic), redox class, cofactor regeneration mode, chronology, reaction types, overall transformation (e.g., deracemization, hydrogen-borrowing), product class, enzyme classes, biocatalyst preparation (purified, CFE, whole cell, immobilized), and spatial organization (co-immobilization, scaffolds, membranes, nanoparticles, flow columns).


Spontaneous cascades triggered by one enzyme: epoxide-hydrolase → THF rings; triterpene cyclases (SHC, BmeTC) for polycyclizations; laccase radical dimerizations; ADH reduction → spontaneous lactonization.


In-vitro cascades (enzyme per step): single-enzyme multi-turnover cases, two-enzyme and 3–6+ enzyme lines; major families include hydrogen-borrowing and redox-neutral cascades; simultaneous vs sequential staging; flow implementations.


Chemoenzymatic combinations: enzymes + chemical reagents or metal catalysts, in both simultaneous and staged modes, plus flow chemoenzymatic cascades.


Artificial in-vivo cascades: defined as using metabolism for cofactor recycling or a continuously supplied metabolite; examples with 1–4+ catalysts; single-cell catalysts via co-expression.


Advantages & challenges: avoids intermediate isolation; enables handling of unstable intermediates; but requires compatibility in pH/solvent/temp, attention to thermodynamics and cross-inhibition; sequential staging or compartmentalization can resolve conflicts; overall TON limited by the least stable enzyme.


Key exemplars & metrics


OleT P450 double oxidative decarboxylation of diacids → terminal dienes; example TTN 978, 29% conversion, 0.49 g L⁻¹ product (tetradecanedioic acid → 1,11-dodecadiene).


Convergent redox system: ADH double oxidation of 1,6-hexanediol coupled to BVMO oxidation of cyclohexanone → ε-caprolactone; up to 18.3 mM product in 72 h (≈61% from given loads).


Hydrogen-borrowing alcohol → amine (ADH + TA + AlaDH): quantitative 1,10-decanediol diamination within ~20 h; single-cell E. coli variants demonstrated.


AmDH routes (ADH + AmDH): secondary/primary alcohols → amines with good–excellent ee; racemates via two ADHs or low-selectivity ADH.


Mandelate → L-phenylglycine (racemase + D-mandelate DH + L-LeuDH): 1 L, 200 mM, >96% conversion, 86.5% isolated yield; o-Cl case relevant to clopidogrel intermediate.


Cyclase cascades: BmeTC converts 3-deoxyachilleol A to (+)-ambrein; isolated 4% yield; SHC variants cyclize shorter analogs, showcasing engineered Brønsted-acid catalysis scope.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Compatibility conflicts (pH/solvent/temp), thermodynamic bottlenecks, undesired cofactor sinks (e.g., NADH oxidases), and inhibition/cross-reactivity—often solved by sequential staging, flow compartmentalization, or balancing expression in single-cell systems.
Outlook
Growth of multi-enzyme, flow, and chemo-bio hybrid cascades with smarter compartmentalization and substrate channeling; wider use of single-cell catalysts for economy; design guided by thermodynamics and redox bookkeeping.
Tags
Classification; hydrogen-borrowing; redox-neutral; deracemization; simultaneous vs sequential; in-vitro/in-vivo; flow; spatial organization; chemoenzymatic; SHC/cyclases; epoxide hydrolase; laccase; ADH; AmDH/LeuDH; BVMO.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/18_Wachtme.title: 18_Wachtmeister_2016_CurrOpinBiotechnol
backbone/core_reviews/summary/18_Wachtme.content:
Recent advances in whole-cell biocatalysis techniques: bridging from investigative to industrial scale (Wachtmeister & Rother, Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 2016)
Citation & scope
Survey of whole-cell catalysts from lab to plant: cost/stability advantages, unconventional media, cofactor strategies, cascades, immobilization, transport/mass-transfer engineering, and reactor/flow concepts.
Thesis / what’s new
Whole cells cut cost (no purification), supply/regenerate cofactors, and tolerate harsher media; paired with unconventional solvents, smart cofactor regeneration, and novel reactors, they can reach productivities beyond typical industrial benchmarks.
Higher-order topic map (as framed by the review)


Economics & formulation — whole cells ≈ order-of-magnitude cheaper than purified enzymes; immobilization carriers add cost.


Cofactor & redox strategies — classical NAD(P)H recycling; redox-neutral cascades (e.g., ADH↔MOx), “smart diol” cosubstrates forming lactones (thermo push, 2 e⁻/molecule).


Unconventional media — neat-substrate systems (NSS), micro-aqueous organic (e.g., MTBE), ionic liquids (ILs), and deep eutectic solvents (DES).


Multistep & cascades — co-/separate expression; redox-self-sufficient and recycling cascades.


Overcoming mass transfer — permeabilization; transporter plug-ins (e.g., AlkL); surface display; membrane-anchor + phage-pore lysis to create catalytic cell-envelope particles.


Immobilization & recovery — Lentikats (PVA lenses), silicone-coated composites (silCoat), GA crosslinking, “teabag catalysis” in PVDF sachets.


Reactor concepts & scale-up — parallel mini-reactors that scale, microtiter biphasic screening, packed columns, SpinChem rotating bed, and continuous/flow with in-line capture or in-situ reagent generation (e.g., cyanide).


Regulatory & downstream — API production feasible with dead cells; DSP solutions exist; host knockouts mitigate side reactions.


Key exemplars & metrics


NSS, ADH reductions: (S)-phenylethanol 300–500 g/L, ee > 99%; other system 634 g/L product.


Continuous 2-butanol (R/S): up to 2278 g L⁻¹ d⁻¹ (R) at 96.6% ee; 180–461 g L⁻¹ d⁻¹ (S), ee 98%.


Micro-aqueous MTBE carboligation → diol: up to 49 g/L product; 327 g L⁻¹ d⁻¹ STY; cyanohydrins ee > 98%.


ILs/DES: IL compatibility trends (short-chain imidazoliums); example 987 mM chiral alcohol with recombinant E. coli.


Transporter engineering: AlkL boosts cell-specific yields up to 100-fold for C7–C16 alkanes.


Surface display P450: TON > 54,000; improved stability and reuse.


Immobilization: Lentikats strong, store ≤15 months; silicone coatings enable NSS use; teabags recycle well at 400 mM loads.


Scale-down/-up parity: 48×10 mL IL-biphasic reactors match 200 mL; microtiter (1.2 mL) predictive for 120 mL/1.2 L.


Flow & continuous: closed-loop cyanohydrin synthesis with in-situ CN⁻ generation; packed-bed with lyophilized E. coli; SpinChem reduces abrasion without rate loss.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Mass-transfer barriers; toxicity of hydrophobic substrates; IL “greenness” reevaluation (ecotoxicity/production waste); need for benign solvents (e.g., 2-MeTHF).
Outlook
Best-in-class processes will pair whole-cell robustness in unconventional media with atom-efficient cofactor schemes, immobilization for reuse, and continuous reactors; integration with renewable feedstocks strengthens economics and sustainability.
Tags
Whole-cell; cost & stability; NAD(P)H regeneration; redox-neutral cascades; smart diols; NSS; micro-aqueous; IL/DES; transporters (AlkL); permeabilization; surface display; Lentikats; silCoat; teabag catalysis; SpinChem; flow/continuous; regulatory/DSP.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/19_Lin_201.title: 19_Lin_2017_MicrobCellFact
backbone/core_reviews/summary/19_Lin_201.content:
Whole-cell biocatalysts by design (Lin & Tao, Microbial Cell Factories 2017)
Citation & scope
Review of strategies to design and optimize whole-cell biocatalysts, with emphasis on E. coli chassis, covering pathway construction, metabolic/chassis engineering, cofactor strategies, transport/mass-transfer, and process engineering.
Thesis / what’s new
Whole-cell systems are increasingly rationally designed (synthetic biology + metabolic engineering) to convert cheap feedstocks into value-added chemicals; success hinges on maximizing pathway flux, balancing cofactors/precursors, and engineering the chassis as much as the enzymes.
Higher-order topic map (as framed by the review)


Why whole cells: inherent cofactor supply, multistep cascades, cost advantages; key drawbacks are membrane mass-transfer limits and side metabolism.


Pathway construction: single-step, multistep (heterologous), and de-novo synthetic pathways; separate growth vs. production phases.


Pathway optimization: identify bottlenecks; balance expression (promoters/RBS/codon/gene order); block competing pathways; boost precursor supply.


Cofactor & redox engineering: classical NAD(P)H recycling (FDH/GDH etc.); self-sufficient redox cascades; 2-oxoglutarate reuse via a modified TCA cycle; “bridging” designs to regenerate multiple cofactors simultaneously.


Chassis engineering: uptake/efflux tuning (e.g., AlkL), reduce product/substrate degradation, mitigate proteolysis.


Process engineering: biomass formation cost vs. activity; permeabilization (surfactants/solvents, temperature shock); two-phase systems.


Control strategies: dynamic regulation to decouple growth and production.


Key exemplars & metrics


“Natural” label economics: 2-phenylethanol by bioprocess 20.4–26.5 g/L (≈0.3 g L⁻¹ h⁻¹) vs. much cheaper petro-route product label; price premium drives viability.


Single-step: esterase EstK1 in E. coli → cinnamyl acetate; 94–97% conversion in 1–2 h.


Single-step (GABA): overexpressed GAD with host deletions → 614 g/L GABA, >99% molar yield.


Multistep (2-PE): Ehrlich or PAAS pathways transplanted to E. coli; de-novo PLP-only route produced 0.34 g/L.


De-novo Neu5Ac: AGE + NanA (or NeuB) in E. coli → up to 74.2 g/L Neu5Ac; 6.2 g L⁻¹ h⁻¹; recyclable ≥5 cycles. Knocking out nanTEK boosted titers to 173.8 mM.


Combinatorial pathway tuning (OLMA): lycopene pathway library raised yield from 0.14 → 15.17 mg/g DCW.


Cofactor strategies: classic FDH/GDH NAD(P)H recycling; self-sufficient redox amination (ADH + transaminase + AlaDH); in-vitro hydrogen-borrowing ADH+AmDH cascade.


2-OG as “cofactor”: re-wired TCA to force flux through DAOCS → 11-fold efficiency boost for penicillin-G → 7-ADCA.


Transport engineering: AlkL improves uptake for ω-oxyfunctionalization; overexpression can toxify—tune expression to jump from 4.3 → 229 g/L in two-phase setups.


Permeabilization: Triton X-100, Tween-80, xylene, CTAB—useful but trade-offs with leakage/downstream burden.


Limits / gaps (authors’ view)
Mass-transfer barriers; side metabolism and product/substrate degradation; rigid gene over/under-expression in central metabolism harms growth; need dynamic control to toggle growth vs. production and avoid toxic intermediates.
Outlook
Rationally designed whole-cell catalysts will expand via combinatorial DNA assembly, systems-level flux control, self-sufficient cofactor networks, and dynamic gene circuits—with E. coli remaining a prime chassis but concepts transferable to other hosts.
Tags
Whole-cell biocatalysis; E. coli chassis; pathway construction; bottlenecks & balancing; precursor supply; NAD(P)H recycling; self-sufficient redox; 2-OG/TCA rewiring; transporter engineering; permeabilization; dynamic control; Neu5Ac; GABA; lycopene; 2-phenylethanol.

backbone/core_reviews/summary/20_Buller_.title: 20_Buller_2023_Science
backbone/core_reviews/summary/20_Buller_.content:
From nature to industry: Harnessing enzymes for biocatalysis (Buller, Lutz, Kazlauskas, Snajdrova, Moore, Bornscheuer, Science 2023)
Thesis / what’s new
Explains how a decade of new experimental (DNA read/write, automation/HTS, continuous and cell-free evolution, ncAA) and in-silico (structure prediction, design, ML) tools now let us discover, redesign, or de-novo create enzymes and deploy them in cascades for drugs, materials, and recycling; biocatalysis stands as a peer to traditional catalysis and is expanding into new-to-nature reactivity.
Higher-order topic map (as framed by the review)


Sourcing & Discovery – natural diversity mining, metagenomes, legacy enzyme panels/kits; sequence-/structure-guided triage.


Engineering Strategies – (i) repurposing & substrate walking, (ii) mechanism redesign (e.g., P450→carbene/nitrene; flavin radical chemistry), (iii) computational de-novo design refined by evolution.


Experimental Tooling – enzymatic DNA synthesis (TdT), oligo-pools, cell-free expression, continuous evolution, microfluidic ultrahigh-throughput screening, cryo-EM/MicroED, non-canonical amino acids for tuning or photochemistry.


In-silico Tooling – AlphaFold/RoseTTAFold/ESMFold; docking/completion (AlphaFill, DiffDock); ML for function/selectivity; dynamics (MD; shortest-path maps); data standards (EnzymeML).


Process Architectures – (chemo)enzymatic cascades, metabolic pathway planning, retrosynthesis planners (e.g., RetroBioCat), cofactor/solvent compatibility design.


Application Domains – pharmaceuticals (API/intermediates), biotherapeutics (insulin conjugation, oligos), materials & circularity (PET depolymerization), flavors/fragrances (Ambrofix), C1/CO2 routes (starch from methanol).


Integration with Other Catalysis – photo-, electro-, and transition-metal hybridizations.


Metrics & Scale – PMI reduction, high substrate loads, productivities; emphasis on standardized, reproducible data for ML.


Limits / Open Problems – need for cleaner datasets, better design of dynamics/allostery and long-range effects; initial activity of de-novo enzymes often low; scaling enzymatic oligo synthesis supply chain.


Future Directions – faster design-build-test (automation + ML + continuous/cell-free), democratized planning tools, expansion of new-to-nature chemistry and circular manufacturing.


Key exemplars & metrics (for your later tables)


PET recycling: engineered cutinase (LCC mutant) run at industrial scale; >95% conversion with 200 g/L load; productivity 16.5 g·L⁻¹·h⁻¹.


Molnupiravir cascade: 3 enzymes (+auxiliaries), PMI 125, substrate load 30 g/L, productivity 131 g·L⁻¹·d⁻¹, 69% overall yield.


Islatravir cascade: 5 enzymes (+4 auxiliaries), PMI 360, load 200 mM, 16 g·L⁻¹·d⁻¹, 51% overall yield.


BMS-986278 intermediate (ERED+KRED one-pot): PMI 170 vs 2017 for legacy route; >99% conv., >99% de/ee; load 67 g/L.


Ambrofix: single engineered SHC from homofarnesol; >95% yield at 300 g/L substrate.


TdT enzymatic DNA synthesis: per-step incorporation >99.6%; lengths up to ~1000 nt.


New-to-nature reactivity: engineered P450 “P411” for sp³ C–H functionalization/amination; flavin ERED photocatalysis enabling radical cross-electrophile coupling/cyclizations.


Limits / gaps (explicit)


De-novo designs start weak; extensive directed evolution still required.


ML needs standardized, clean sequence–function datasets; better handling of dynamics, cofactors, PTMs.


Enzymatic oligo synthesis: feedstock supply/cost (unprotected NTPs) and scale remain open.


Outlook (authors)

Routine data-driven enzyme design with experimental standardization, continuous evolution, and automation; wider retrosynthetic tools for non-experts; enzymes central to complex therapeutics, renewables, and waste reduction.

Tags
Discovery; Directed-evolution; Mechanism-redesign; De-novo design; DNA read/write; Cell-free/continuous evolution; Microfluidics HTS; ncAA photobiocatalysis; Structure prediction & design; ML for function; Cascades; Chemo-bio hybrids; APIs/biotherapeutics; Plastics recycling; C1/CO₂ conversion; Metrics (PMI, load, productivity).

home.title: home
home.content:
Web of Biocatalysis
A living backbone of the field, continuously updated and re-interpreted.

What is this?
The Web of Biocatalysis is not a frozen review article.
It is a living map: connecting pillars of knowledge, highlighting key papers,
tracking trends, and linking to curated data.

It grows over time.
It updates with new insights.
It shows both history and horizon.


The Pillars
Biocatalysis is structured here into ten interconnected pillars.
Click into any pillar to explore its live article, curated data, and evolving feed.

Discovery & Sourcing of Biocatalysts
Design & Engineering
Biocatalyst Formats & Cellular Context
Media & Microenvironment
Immobilization & Materials
Cofactor & Energy Management
Cascade & Route Design
Reactors, Flow & In-Line Operations
Reaction Space & Enzyme Portfolios
Sustainability, Metrics & Industrialization


Live Articles
Each pillar is presented as a live article:

Overview of core concepts
Curated tables of examples & metrics
News feed of recent papers
Historical snapshots & landmark studies
Interpretation: what’s emerging, what’s fading


Why “Web”?
Because knowledge here is not linear.

A discovery in Design links to implications in Sustainability.
A new Cascade strategy reshapes Reaction Portfolios.
Everything is connected.

This is interpretation, not just data.

Explore
Start with Pillar 1: Discovery & Sourcing of Biocatalysts
Or jump into the Latest Additions

pillars/02_design_engineering/pillar-02-.title: pillar-02-design_engineering
pillars/02_design_engineering/pillar-02-.content:
Pillar 02 — Design & Engineering
A living article for the Design & Engineering pillar. Stable structure below; generated sections are injected at compile time.
Overview
Protein engineering refers to the intentional modification of amino-acid sequences, reshaping folded structure and function so catalysts meet defined goals in activity, selectivity, stability, tolerance, and substrate scope. [1][2] This pillar brings together rational design, semi-rational focused libraries, and directed evolution: sequence-informed edits (consensus) articulate hypotheses, focused saturation explores active-site windows with compact libraries, and iterative evolution delivers process fitness under manufacturing criteria. [3][4][2][5] The toolkit includes CAST-style active-site saturation, million-member picodroplet discovery from metagenomes, and growth-amplified clonal droplet assays that enhance sensitivity and DNA recovery. [4][6][7]
In practice, these modes form a continuum: stabilize or bias the scaffold with sequence-guided edits, confine variation to targeted positions, then iterate improvements with scalable screens when a selection signal exists. [3][4][2][7][6] Droplet microfluidics and functional metagenomics provide ultrahigh-throughput and sensitivity, while large screening programs broaden accessible chemical space. [7][6][8] ML-guided strategies are not substantiated by this evidence set. Together, this layered playbook yields robust, selective, process-fit catalysts and interfaces directly with downstream assays, media, expression formats, cascades, and reactor engineering across the Web of Biocatalysis. [1][2]

pillars/02_design_engineering/sections/g.title: history_narrative
pillars/02_design_engineering/sections/g.content:
Biocatalysis has seen significant advancements, particularly in the development and optimization of enzymes for industrial applications. According to a 2021 review in Nature Reviews Methods Primers, tailor-made enzymes with high efficiencies and selectivities can now be produced quickly on a gram to kilogram scale, thanks to dedicated databases and search tools. This progress highlights the growing importance of biocatalysis in organic synthesis and chemical manufacturing.
Moreover, the use of directed evolution techniques has greatly enhanced enzyme performance. For instance, the 2019 PNAS study demonstrated how machine learning-assisted directed protein evolution with combinatorial libraries can significantly improve protein function outside their natural contexts. Similarly, the 2018 ACS Synthetic Biology paper introduced “site and mutation”-specific predictions for minimal directed evolution libraries, further refining the process of enzyme optimization. These advancements underscore the versatility and potential of biocatalysis in addressing complex chemical challenges.

pillars/02_design_engineering/sections/g.title: overview
pillars/02_design_engineering/sections/g.content:
Biocatalysis has seen significant advancements, particularly in the development and optimization of enzymes for industrial applications [S12]. Enzymes can now be produced quickly on a gram to kilogram scale, with dedicated databases and search tools making these biocatalysts more accessible [S12]. These tailor-made enzymes exhibit high efficiencies and selectivities, making them invaluable in various chemical processes. Techniques such as immobilization have further improved enzyme activity, stability, and selectivity, enabling their use in diverse settings [S3].
Moreover, the field of biocatalysis is increasingly leveraging advanced methodologies like directed evolution and machine learning to enhance enzyme performance [S10][S14]. For instance, structure-guided directed evolution has been used to expand the substrate scope of halogenases for asymmetric C(sp³)–H chlorination [S13], while cryo-EM structures have provided insights into nitrilase specificity [S15]. These approaches not only improve enzyme functionality but also enable their use in novel applications, driving innovation in organic synthesis and biotechnology.
